Although Irving is introduced in the festival's webpages as "historian and writer" the board chair leader defended the more aggressive language being used to characterize Irving in connection with the controversy that had arisen. [[Lars Saabye Christensen]] and [[Roy Jacobsen]] were two authors who had threatened to boycott the festival on account of Irving's invitation and [[Anne B. Ragde]] stated that [[Sigrid Undset]] would have turned around in her grave. As the festival has as its subsidiary name "Sigrid Undset Days", a representative of Undset's family had requested that the name of the Nobel laureate be removed in connection with the festival.{{cite news|first=Geir |last=Rakvaag |title=Irving fortsatt invitert |url=http://www.dagsavisen.no/kultur/article372935.ece |work=[[Dagsavisen]] |location=Oslo |date=7 October 2008 |accessdate=8 October 2008 |language=Norwegian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008174519/http://www.dagsavisen.no/kultur/article372935.ece |archivedate=8 October 2008 |df=dmy }}{{cite news |first= Vibecke |last= Wold Haagensen |title= Irving invitert som løgner |url= http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/hedmark_og_oppland/1.6252043 |publisher= [[NRK]] |location= [[Hedmark]]/[[Oppland]] |date=7 October 2008 |accessdate=8 October 2008 |language= Norwegian}} Also the Norwegian [[free speech]] organization [[Fritt Ord (organization)|Fritt Ord]] was critical towards letting Irving speak at the festival{{cite news |title= Holocaust denier unwelcome in Norway |url= http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2008/10/09/Holocaust_denier_unwelcome_in_Norway/UPI-56301223577740/ |agency = [[United Press International|UPI]] |date=9 October 2008 |accessdate=10 October 2008}} and had requested that its logo be removed from the festival.{{cite news|title=Holocaust denial speaker's invitation cancelled |url=http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article2704141.ece |work=[[Aftenposten]] |location=Oslo, Norway |date=9 October 2008 |accessdate=10 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010220014/http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article2704141.ece |archivedate=10 October 2008 |df=dmy }} In addition [[Edvard Hoem]] announced that he would not attend the 2009 festival with Irving taking part. [[Per Edgar Kokkvold]], leader of the [[Norwegian Press Confederation]] advocated cancelling Irving's invitation.{{cite news |first= Olav |last= Østrem |title= Sæterbakken slår tilbake |url= http://www.klassekampen.no/55114/article/item/null |work= [[Klassekampen]] |location= Oslo, Norway |date= 9 October 2008 |accessdate= 10 October 2008 |language= Norwegian |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081012070848/http://klassekampen.no/55114/article/item/null |archivedate= 12 October 2008 |df= dmy-all }} Days after the controversy had started, the invitation was rescinded. This led to the resignation of [[Stig Sæterbakken]] from his position as content director as he was the person who had invited Irving to the event. The head of the Norwegian Festival of Literature, Randi Skeie, deplored what had taken place, stating "Everything is fine as long as everyone agrees, but things get more difficult when one doesn't like the views being put forward." Sæterbakken characterized his colleagues as "damned cowards" arguing that they were walking in lockstep.{{cite news |first= Geir |last= Olsen |authorlink= Geir Olsen |title= Retrett mot Davig Irving. Irving: – De tør ikke møte meg |url= http://www.vg.no/rampelys/artikkel.php?artid=528392 |work= [[Verdens Gang]] |location= Oslo, Norway |date= 10 October 2008 |accessdate=15 October 2008 |language= Norwegian}} According to editor-in-chief Sven Egil Omdal of ''[[Stavanger Aftenblad]]'' the opposition to Irving's participation at the festival appeared as a concerted effort and Omdal suggested [[campaign journalism]] from two of Norway's largest newspapers, ''[[Dagbladet]]'' and ''[[Aftenposten]]'' and Norway's public service broadcaster [[NRK]].{{cite news |first= Sven Egil |last= Omdal |authorlink= Sven Egil Omdal |title= Ikke fullt så Fritt Ord |url= http://www.aftenbladet.no/debatt/medieblikk/927176/Ikke_fullt_saa_Fritt_Ord.html |work= [[Stavanger Aftenblad]] |location= [[Stavanger]], Norway |date= 11 October 2008 |accessdate= 15 October 2008 |language= Norwegian |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5ihrmyJqg?url=http://www.aftenbladet.no/debatt/medieblikk/927176/Ikke_fullt_saa_Fritt_Ord.html |archivedate= 1 August 2009 |df= dmy-all }} David Irving commented that he had not been told that the festival was going to present him as a liar, and that he was preparing a lecture about the real history of what took place in [[Occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany|Norway during World War II]], contrary to what official historians have presented. Irving stated that he had thought the Norwegian people to be made of tougher stuff.{{cite news |first= Ann |last= Christiansen |title= Irving: – Utsatt for global kampanje |url= http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article2703646.ece |work= [[Aftenposten]] |location= Oslo, Norway |date= 9 October 2008 |accessdate= 15 October 2008 |language= Norwegian |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081012211137/http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article2703646.ece |archivedate= 12 October 2008 |df= dmy-all }} Only days after the cancellation David Irving announced that he would go to Lillehammer during the literature festival and deliver his 2-hour lecture from a hotel room.{{cite news |first= Andreas |last= Wiese |title= David Irving rir igjen |url= http://www.dagbladet.no/nyheter/2008/10/15/550314.html |work= [[Dagbladet]] |location= Oslo, Norway |date= 15 October 2008 |accessdate= 15 October 2008 |language= Norwegian |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081017085639/http://www.dagbladet.no/nyheter/2008/10/15/550314.html |archivedate= 17 October 2008 |df= dmy-all }} ==Reception by historians== {{main|Critical responses to David Irving}} Irving, once held in regard for his expert knowledge of German military archives, was a controversial figure from the start. His interpretations of the war were widely regarded as unduly favourable to the German side. At first this was seen as personal opinion, unpopular but consistent with full respectability as a historian.{{Harvnb|Lipstadt|2005|p=22}}. By 1988, however, Irving had begun to reject the status of the Holocaust as a systematic and deliberate genocide. He soon became the main proponent of Holocaust denial. This, along with his association with far-right circles, dented his standing as a historian. A marked change in Irving's reputation can be seen in the surveys of the [[historiography of the Third Reich]] produced by [[Ian Kershaw]]. In the first edition of Kershaw's book ''The Nazi Dictatorship'' in 1985, Irving was called a "maverick" historian working outside the mainstream of the historical profession.{{Harvnb|Kershaw|1985|p=150}}. By the time of the fourth edition of ''The Nazi Dictatorship'' in 2000, Irving was described only as a historical writer who had in the 1970s engaged in "provocations" intended to provide an "exculpation of Hitler's role in the Final Solution".{{Harvnb|Kershaw|1985|p=268}}. Other critical responses to his work tend to follow this pattern. The description of Irving as a historian, rather than a historical author, is controversial, with some publications since the libel trial continuing to refer to him as a "historian"e.g. [https://www.theguardian.com/irving/ The Guardian] or "disgraced historian",Philippe Naughton and agencies in Vienna. [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,13509-2049360,00.html "Irving jailed for three years, despite Holocaust U-turn"], ''[[The Times]],'' 20 February 2006. while others insist he is not a historian, and have adopted alternatives such as "author""In 1969 ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' determined 'It is incorrect to describe David Irving as a historian. In future we should describe him as an author.'" {{cite news |last= Ingrams |first= Richard |url= http://comment.independent.co.uk/commentators/article347567.ece |title= Irving was the author of his own downfall |work= [[The Independent]] |date= 25 February 2006 |location= London |accessdate= 27 March 2010 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071220125920/http://comment.independent.co.uk/commentators/article347567.ece |archivedate= 20 December 2007 |df= dmy-all }} or "historic writer"."...Irving is not a historian. Those in the know, indeed, are accustomed to avoid the term altogether when referring to him and use some circumlocution such as 'historical writer' instead." Irving vs. (1) Lipstadt and (2) Penguin Books, [http://hdot.org/en/trial/defense/evans/6.html Expert Witness Report by [[Richard J. Evans]] FBA, Professor of Modern History, [[University of Cambridge]]], 2000, Chapter 6. The military historian [[John Keegan]] praised Irving for his "extraordinary ability to describe and analyse Hitler's conduct of military operations, which was his main occupation during the [[Second World War]]".John Keegan, {{cite web |url=http://portal.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=%2Farchive%2F2000%2F04%2F12%2Fnirv512.html |title=The trial of David Irving—and my part in his downfall |accessdate=25 February 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040627233112/http://portal.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=%2Farchive%2F2000%2F04%2F12%2Fnirv512.html |archivedate=27 June 2004 |df=dmy-all }}. ''The Daily Telegraph'' (UK). 12 April 2000 Donald Cameron Watt, [[Emeritus Professor]] of Modern History at the [[London School of Economics]], wrote that he admires some of Irving's work as a historian, though he rejects his conclusions about the Holocaust.{{cite news |title=History needs David Irvings|first=Donald |last=Cameron Watt |work= London Evening Standard |date= 11 April 2000}} At the libel proceedings against Irving, Watt declined Irving's request to testify, appearing only after a [[subpoena]] was ordered.{{Harvnb|Guttenplan|2001|p=128}}. He testified that Irving had written a "very, very effective piece of historical scholarship" in the 1960s, which was unrelated to his controversial work. He also said that Irving was "not in the top class" of military historians. "'''Dictatorships and Double Standards'''" is an essay by [[Jeane Kirkpatrick]], published<ref>Jeane Kirkpatrick, "[https://www.commentarymagazine.com/article/dictatorships-double-standards]," ''[[Commentary Magazine]]''. Volume 68, No. 5, November 1979, pp. 34–45. & [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0671438360 Related book]</ref> in the November 1979 issue of ''[[Commentary (magazine)|Commentary Magazine]]'', which criticized the [[foreign policy]] of the [[Jimmy Carter|Carter administration]]. It is also the title of a 270-page book written by Kirkpatrick in 1982.<ref>''Dictatorships and Double Standards: Rationalism and Reason in Politics'', 1982 ({{ISBN|0-671-43836-0}})</ref>
The article in ''Commentary Magazine'' in 1979 is credited with leading directly to Kirkpatrick's becoming an adviser to [[Ronald Reagan]] and thus her appointment as [[United States Ambassador to the United Nations]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Tim |last=Weiner |title=Jeane Kirkpatrick, Reagan’s Forceful Envoy, Dies |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/09/washington/09kirkpatrick.html?pagewanted=print |work=The New York Times |date=2006-12-09 |accessdate=2008-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Timothy |last=Noah |authorlink=Timothy Noah |title=The Elusive Ronald Reagan |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/28/AR2007032801933_pf.html |work=The Washington Post |page=C04 |date=2007-03-29 |accessdate=2008-09-13}}</ref> Hence, the views expressed in Kirkpatrick's essay influenced the foreign policy of the Reagan administration, particularly with regard to Latin America.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/opinion/blumenthal/2006/12/14/jeane_kirkpatrick/ |title=Mugged by reality |accessdate=2008-09-13 |last=Blumenthal |first=Sidney |authorlink=Sidney Blumenthal |date=2006-12-14 |work=Salon}}</ref>
Kirkpatrick argued that by demanding rapid liberalization in traditionally [[Autocracy|autocrat]]ic countries, the Carter administration (and previous administrations) had delivered those countries to [[anti-American]] opposition groups that proved more repressive than the governments they overthrew. She further accused the administration of a "double standard" in that it had never applied its rhetoric on the necessity of liberalization to the affairs of [[Communist state|Communist governments]].
The essay compares traditional autocracies and Communist regimes:
{{quote|[Traditional autocrats] do not disturb the habitual rhythms of work and leisure, habitual places of residence, habitual patterns of family and personal relations. Because the miseries of traditional life are familiar, they are bearable to ordinary people who, growing up in the society, learn to cope . . . .
[Revolutionary Communist regimes] claim jurisdiction over the whole life of the society and make demands for change that so violate internalized values and habits that inhabitants flee by the tens of thousands . . . .}}
Kirkpatrick concluded that while the United States should encourage liberalization and democracy in autocratic countries, it should not do so when the government is facing violent overthrow, and should expect gradual change rather than immediate transformation.
==Criticism== The [[AFL-CIO]]'s [[Tom Kahn]] criticized conceptual problems and strategic consequences in Kirkpatrick's analysis. In particular, Kahn suggested that policy should [[democracy promotion|promote democracy]] even in the countries dominated by [[Soviet communism]]. Kahn argued that the Polish labor-union Solidarity deserved U.S. support and even in its first years demonstrated that [[civil society]] could expand and that free [[labor unions]] could be organized, despite communist regimes. Kirkpatrick's analysis of communism underestimated the democratic potential of the working class.<ref>{{citation<!-- allows "others=" unlike cite journal-->|title=Beyond the double standard: A social democratic view of the authoritarianism versus totalitarianism debate|first=Tom|last=Kahn|authorlink=Tom Kahn|journal=New America|publisher=[[Social Democrats, USA]]|date=July 1985 |url=http://www.dissentmagazine.org/wp-content/files_mf/1389820828d12Kahn.pdf|format=pdf|others=January 1985 speech to the ‘Democratic Solidarity Conference’ organized by the Young Social Democrats (YSD) under the auspices of the Foundation for Democratic Education|ref=harv}} : Reprinted: {{cite journal |title=Beyond the double standard: A social democratic view of the authoritarianism versus totalitarianism debate |last=Kahn |first=Tom |4= |journal=[[Democratiya]] ''(merged into'' [[Dissent (American magazine)|Dissent]] ''in 2009)'' |volume=12 |issue=Spring |year=2008 |origyear=1985 |pages=152–60 |url=http://www.dissentmagazine.org/democratiya/docs/d12Kahn.pdf |format=pdf |ref=harv }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} </ref>
Ted Galen Carpenter of the [[Cato Institute]] noted that while Communist movements tend to depose rival authoritarians, the traditional authoritarian regimes supported by the US came to power by overthrowing democracies. He thus concludes that while Communist regimes are more difficult to eradicate, traditional autocratic regimes "pose the more lethal threat to functioning democracies."<ref>[http://www.cato.org/pubs/pas/pa058.html "The United States and Third World Dictatorships: A Case for Benign Detachment"] Ted Galen Carpenter. Cato Policy Analysis No. 58, August 15, 1985</ref>

{{Libertarianism sidebar}} '''Evictionism''' is a [[Morality|moral theory]] advanced by [[Walter Block]] and Roy Whitehead on a proposed [[Libertarianism|libertarian]] view of [[abortion]] based on [[property rights]]. This theory is built upon the earlier work of philosopher [[Murray Rothbard]]<ref>"Literature of liberty," [[Cato Institute]], v. 4, p. 12, 1981.</ref> who wrote that "no being has a right to live, unbidden, as a parasite within or upon some person's body" and that therefore the woman is entitled to eject the baby from her body at any time.<ref>{{cite book|title=For a New Liberty|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=B65ic_7bfFEC&printsec=frontcover&dq=For+a+New+Liberty&hl=en&ei=_4ZpTOCuLoH58Abl8OyyBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=abortion&f=false 131–132]|chapter=Personal Liberty|author=Rothbard, Murray|isbn=0-930073-02-9}}</ref> Evictionists view a mother's womb as her property and an unwanted fetus as a "trespasser or parasite", even while lacking the will to act. They argue that a mother has the right to evict a fetus from her body since she has no obligation to care for a trespasser. The authors' hope is that bystanders will "[[Homestead principle|homestead]]" the right to care for evicted babies and reduce the number of human deaths. They argue that life begins at conception and state that the act of abortion must be conceptually separated into the acts of: # the eviction of the [[fetus]] from the womb, and # the [[Homicide|killing]] of the baby. Building on the libertarian stand against [[trespass]] and [[murder]], Block supports a right to the first act (eviction), but not the second act (murder).
Walter Block believes the woman always has a right to evict but may only legally abort if the fetus is not [[Fetal viability|viable]] outside the womb, or # the woman has publicly announced her abandonment of the right to [[Child custody|custody]] of the fetus, and # no one else has "[[Homestead principle|homesteaded]]" that right by offering to care for the resulting baby.<ref name="Block">*Walter Block, Roy Whitehead, [http://www.walterblock.com/wp-content/uploads/publications/block-whitehead_abortion-2005.pdf ''Compromising the Uncompromisable: A Private Property Approach to Resolving the Abortion Controversy''], [http://www.walterblock.com Walter Block personal web site.]</ref><ref>Jakub Bozydar Wisniewski, [http://libertarianpapers.org/articles/2010/lp-2-16.pdf "A Critique of Block on Abortion and Child Abandonment"], LibertariansPapers.org, project of [[Ludwig Von Mises Institute]], VOL. 2, ART. NO. 16 (2010)</ref>
==Embryonic research== Likewise, Block proposes that medical experimenters can treat the embryos they have in their possession as laboratory "[[Animal testing|animals]]", as is their desire, contingent on only one stipulation: that no one else wishes to [[Parenting|raise]] these very young infants on their own. If there are adoptive parents who wish to homestead the right to care for the children, their rights trump those of the creators of the fertilized egg since the former wishes to protect the child from harm, while the latter does not. Thus Block offers an alternative to the standard choice between the [[pro-life]] and [[pro-choice]] positions on [[stem cell]] research.<ref>Block, Walter. 2010. [http://jmp.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/jhq033?ijkey=oczT7ytzmoAD1cz&keytype=ref ''A Libertarian Perspective on the Stem Cell Debate: Compromising the Uncompromisible,''] ''Journal of Medicine and Philosophy''.  Vol. 35: 429-448</ref>
==Advances in technology== Evictionists believe that advances in technology will continue to improve the medical ability to preserve a living fetus after removal from its mother. This future technology is hoped to save the lives of evicted fetuses at increasingly younger ages whereas aborted fetuses would continue to die at any age.<ref name=Block />
During the past several decades, neonatal care has improved with advances in medical science, and therefore the [[Fetal viability#Limit of viability|limit of viability]] has moved earlier.<ref>''Roe v. Wade'', [http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?navby=CASE&court=US&vol=410&page=113 410 U.S. 113] (1973) ("viability is usually placed at about seven months (28 weeks) but may occur earlier, even at 24 weeks.") Retrieved 2007-03-04.</ref> The lower limit of viability is approximately five months [[gestational age]], and usually later.<ref>Halamek, Louis. "[http://neoreviews.aappublications.org/cgi/content/extract/4/6/e153 Prenatal Consultation at the Limits of Viability]", ''NeoReviews'', Vol.4 No.6 (2003): "most neonatologists would agree that survival of infants younger than approximately 22 to 23 weeks’ estimated gestational age [i.e. 20 to 21 weeks' estimated fertilization age] is universally dismal and that resuscitative efforts should not be undertaken when a neonate is born at this point in pregnancy."</ref>
==Criticism== [[Jakub Wisniewski]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wiśniewski|first=Jakub|title=Response to Block on Abortion, Round Three|journal=Libertarian Papers|year=2011|volume=3|issue=6|url=http://libertarianpapers.org/2011/6-winiewski-response-to-block-on-abortion-round-three/|accessdate=7 September 2012}}</ref> and [[Sean Parr (philosopher)|Sean Parr]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Parr|first=Sean|title=Departurism and the Libertarian Axiom of Gentleness|journal=Libertarian Papers|year=2011|volume=3|issue=34|url=http://libertarianpapers.org/2011/34-parr-departurism/|accessdate=7 September 2012}}</ref> have made counter arguments to evictionism.
== See also == * [[Libertarian perspectives on abortion]] * [[Non-aggression principle]]

Block, “Evictionism is Libertarian; Departurism is Not: Critical Comment on Parr,” Libertarian Papers 3, 36 (2011). ONLINE AT: libertarianpapers.org] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QNTAmwUHcLM Evictionism: Abortion and Libertarianism (Walter Block), YouTube]

The '''extreme weather events of 535–536''' were the most severe and protracted short-term episodes of cooling in the [[Northern Hemisphere]] in the last 2000 years.<ref name=Abbott08>{{cite journal |author=Abbott, D. H.; Biscaye, P.; Cole-Dai, J.; Breger, D. |title=Magnetite and Silicate Spherules from the GISP2 Core at the 536 A.D. Horizon |booktitle=American Geophysical Union, Fall Meeting 2008 |id=Abstract #PP41B-1454 |date=December 2008 |pages=1454 |journal=AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts |bibcode=2008AGUFMPP41B1454A |last2=Biscaye |last3=Cole-Dai |last4=Breger |volume=41}}</ref> The event is thought to have been caused by an extensive atmospheric dust veil, possibly resulting from a large volcanic eruption in the tropics,<ref name="Larsen">{{cite journal |last1=Larsen |first1=L. B. |title=New ice core evidence for a volcanic cause of the A.D. 536 dust veil |journal=Geophys. Res. Lett.|volume=35 |issue=4|pages=L04708|year=2008|doi=10.1029/2007GL032450 |url=http://www.agu.org/pubs/crossref/2008/2007GL032450.shtml|last2=Vinther|first2=B. M.|last3=Briffa |first3=K. R.|last4=Melvin|first4=T. M.|last5=Clausen|first5=H. B.|last6=Jones|first6=P. D. |last7=Siggaard-Andersen|first7=M.-L.|last8=Hammer|first8=C. U.|last9=Eronen|first9=M. |last10=Grudd |first10=H. |last11=Gunnarson |first11=B. E. |last12=Hantemirov |first12=R. M. |last13=Naurzbaev |first13=M. M. |last14=Nicolussi |first14=K. |bibcode=2008GeoRL..3504708L|display-authors=8 }}</ref> or debris from space impacting the Earth.<ref name="Than">{{cite journal|author=Than, Ker|title=Slam dunks from space led to hazy shade of winter|journal=New Scientist|volume=201|issue=2689|pages=9 |date=3 January 2009|bibcode = 2009NewSc.201....9P |doi = 10.1016/S0262-4079(09)60069-5 }}</ref> Its effects were widespread, causing unseasonal weather, [[crop failure]]s, and [[famine]]s worldwide.<ref name="Than"/>
==Documentary evidence== The [[East Roman Empire|Byzantine]] historian [[Procopius]] recorded of 536, in his report on the wars with the [[Vandals]], "during this year a most dread [[Portent (divination)|portent]] took place. For the sun gave forth its light without brightness … and it seemed exceedingly like the sun in eclipse, for the beams it shed were not clear".<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ochoa, George |author2=Jennifer Hoffman |author3=Tina Tin |title=Climate: the force that shapes our world and the future of life on earth|publisher=Rodale|location=Emmaus, PA|pages=|year=2005|isbn=1-59486-288-5}}, gives this quote as "The Sun gave forth its light without brightness, like the moon during this whole year, and it seemed exceedingly like the Sun in eclipse".</ref><ref>Procopius, with Henry Bronson Dewing, trans., ''Procopius'' (London, England: William Heinemann, 1916), vol. 2: History of the [Vandalic] Wars, Books III and IV, [https://books.google.com/books?id=szQjAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA329#v=onepage p. 329.]</ref>
The Gaelic [[Irish Annals]]<ref>[http://www.ucc.ie/celt/publishd.html Gaelic Irish Annals] translations</ref><ref>[http://www.ucc.ie/celt/publishd.html Documents of Ireland]</ref><ref>[http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/T100005A/index.html The Annals of the Four Masters]</ref> record the following: *"A failure of bread in the year 536 AD" – the [[Annals of Ulster]] *"A failure of bread from the years 536–539 AD" – the [[Annals of Inisfallen]]
Further phenomena were reported by a number of independent contemporary sources: *Low temperatures, even snow during the summer (snow reportedly fell in August in [[China]] during the [[Northern and Southern dynasties]], which caused the harvest there to be delayed)<ref name=Ochoa05_p71>{{cite book|author1=Ochoa, George |author2=Jennifer Hoffman |author3=Tina Tin |title=Climate: the force that shapes our world and the future of life on earth|publisher=Rodale|location=Emmaus, PA|year=2005|page=71|isbn=1-59486-288-5}}</ref> *Crop failures<ref>{{cite book|author=Rosen, William|title=Justinian's flea: Plague, Empire and the Birth of Europe|publisher=Jonathan Cape|location=London|year=2007|isbn=0-224-07369-9}}</ref> *"A dense, dry [[fog]]" in the [[Middle East]], China and [[Europe]]<ref name=Ochoa05_p71/> *Drought in [[Peru]], which affected the [[Moche (culture)|Moche]] culture<ref name=Ochoa05_p71/><ref name="Keys, David Patrick 2000">{{cite book|author=Keys, David Patrick|authorlink=David Keys (author)|title=Catastrophe: an investigation into the origins of the modern world|publisher=Ballantine Pub|location=New York|year=2000|isbn=0-345-40876-4}}</ref>
==Scientific evidence== [[Growth ring|Tree ring]] analysis by [[dendrochronology|dendrochronologist]] [[Mike Baillie]], of the [[Queen's University of Belfast]], shows abnormally little growth in Irish [[oak]] in 536 and another sharp drop in 542, after a partial recovery.<ref>Baillie, M.G.L. (1994). "Dendrochronology Raises Questions About the Nature of the AD 536 Dust-Veil Event." ''[[The Holocene (journal)|The Holocene]]'' fig. 3 p. 215.</ref> Similar patterns are recorded in tree rings from [[Sweden]] and [[Finland]], in [[California]]'s [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]], and in rings from [[Chile]]an ''[[Fitzroya]]'' trees.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} [[Ice core]]s from [[Greenland]] and [[Antarctica]] show evidence of substantial [[sulfate]] deposits in around 534 ± 2, which is evidence of an extensive acidic dust veil.<ref name="Larsen" />
==Possible explanations== It has been conjectured that the changes were due to ashes or dust thrown into the air after the eruption of a [[volcano]] (a phenomenon known as "[[volcanic winter]]"),<ref name="Wohletz">Wohletz, Ken, ''[http://www.ees1.lanl.gov/Wohletz/Krakatau.htm Were the Dark Ages Triggered by Volcano-Related Climate Changes in the 6th Century?]''</ref> or after the impact of a [[comet]]<ref>{{cite journal|author=MacIntyre, Ferren|title=Simultaneous Settlement of Indo-Pacific Extrema?|journal=Rapa Nui Journal|volume=16|issue=2|pages=96–104|year=2002}}</ref> or [[meteorite]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Baillie, M. G. L.|title=Exodus to Arthur: Catastrophic Encounters with Comets|publisher=B.T. Batsford|location=London|year=1999|isbn=0-7134-8352-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rigby |first1=Emma|first2=Melissa|last2=Symonds|first3=Derek|last3=Ward-Thompson|title=A comet impact in AD536? |journal=Astronomy and Geophysics|volume=45|date=February 2004|issue=1|doi=10.1046/j.1468-4004.2003.45123.x|pages=1.23|bibcode = 2004A&G....45a..23R }}</ref> The evidence of sulfate deposits in ice cores strongly supports the volcano hypothesis; the sulfate spike is even more intense than what accompanied the lesser episode of climatic aberration in 1816, popularly known as the "[[Year Without a Summer]]", which has been connected to the explosion of the volcano [[Mount Tambora]] in [[Sumbawa]].<ref name="Larsen" />
In 1984, [[R. B. Stothers]] postulated that the event might have been caused by the volcano [[Rabaul caldera|Rabaul]] in what is now [[New Britain]], near [[Papua New Guinea]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Stothers R.B.|title=Mystery cloud of AD 536|journal=Nature|volume=307|issue=5949|pages=344–5|date=26 January 1984|doi=10.1038/307344a0|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v307/n5949/abs/307344a0.html|bibcode = 1984Natur.307..344S }}</ref>
In 1999, [[David Keys (author)|David Keys]] in his book ''Catastrophe: A Quest for the Origins of the Modern World'' (supported by work of the American [[volcanology|volcanologist]] Ken Wohletz), suggested that the volcano [[Krakatoa]] exploded at the time and caused the changes.<ref name="Wohletz"/> It is suggested that an eruption of Krakatoa described as occurring in 416 by the Javanese ''[[Pararaton|Book of Kings]]'' actually took place in 535–536, there being no other evidence of such an eruption in 416.<ref>Keys (2000), page 385</ref>
In 2009, [[Dallas Abbott]] of [[Columbia University]]'s [[Lamont–Doherty Earth Observatory]] in New York published evidence from Greenland [[ice core]]s that multiple [[comet impact]]s caused the haze. The [[spherules]] found in the ice may originate from terrestrial debris ejected into the atmosphere by an impact event.<ref name=Abbott08/><ref>{{cite journal|title=Comet smashes triggered ancient famine|journal=New Scientist|date=7 January 2009|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20126882.900-comet-smashes-triggered-ancient-famine.html}}</ref>
In 2010, [[Robert Dull]], [[John Southon]], and colleagues presented evidence suggesting a link between the [[Tierra Blanca Joven]] (TBJ) eruption of the [[Lake Ilopango|Ilopango caldera]] in central [[El Salvador]] and the 536 event.<ref>{{cite journal| author=Dull, R., J.R. Southon, S. Kutterolf, A. Freundt, D. Wahl, P. Sheets|title=Did the TBJ Ilopango eruption cause the AD 536 event?|journal=AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|date=13–17 December 2010| bibcode=2010AGUFM.V13C2370D| last2=Southon| last3=Kutterolf| last4=Freundt| last5=Wahl| last6=Sheets| volume=13| pages=2370}}</ref> Although earlier published radiocarbon evidence suggested a two-sigma age range of 408–536,<ref>{{cite journal|doi= 10.2307/971755|author= Dull, R. A., Southon, J. R. & Sheets, P.|title= Volcanism, ecology and culture: a reassessment of the Volcán Ilopango TBJ eruption in the southern Maya realm |journal=Latin American Antiquity|volume=12|issue= 1|pages=25–44|year=2001|jstor= 971755 }}</ref> which is consistent with the global climate downturn, the connection between 536 and Ilopango was not explicitly made until research on Central American Pacific margin marine sediment cores by Steffen Kutterolf and colleagues showed that the [[Plinian eruption|phreatoplinian]] TBJ eruption was much larger than previously thought.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Kutterolf, S. A. Freundt |author2=W. Peréz |title= Pacific offshore record of plinian arc volcanism in Central America: 2. Tephra volumes and erupted masses |journal= Geochemistry Geophysics Geosystems |volume=9, Q02S02|issue= 2|pages= n/a |year=2008|doi=10.1029/2007GC001791|url=http://www.agu.org/journals/ABS/2008/2007GC001791.shtml |bibcode=2008GGG.....902S02K}}</ref> The [[radiocarbon dating|radioactive carbon-14]] in successive growth increments of a single tree that had been killed by a TBJ [[Pyroclastic rock|pyroclastic]] flow was measured in detail using [[accelerator mass spectrometry]]; the results supported the date of 535 as the year in which the tree died. A conservative bulk [[tephra]] volume for the TBJ event of ~84 km<sup>3</sup> was calculated, indicating a large [[Volcanic explosivity index]] 6+ event and a magnitude of 6.9. The results suggest that the Ilopango TBJ eruption size, latitude, and age are consistent with the ice core sulphate records of Larsen et al. 2008.
A 2015 study further supported the theory of a major eruption in "535 or early 536", with North American volcanoes considered a likely candidate. It also identified signals of a second eruption in 539–540, likely to have been in the tropics, which would have sustained the cooling effects of the first eruption through to around 550.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Timing and climate forcing of volcanic eruptions for the past 2,500 years|url = http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nature14565|journal = Nature|pages = 543–549|volume = 523|issue = 7562|doi = 10.1038/nature14565|first = M.|last = Sigl|first2 = M.|last2 = Winstrup|first3 = J. R.|last3 = McConnell|first4 = K. C.|last4 = Welten|first5 = G.|last5 = Plunkett|first6 = F.|last6 = Ludlow|first7 = U.|last7 = Büntgen|first8 = M.|last8 = Caffee|first9 = N.|last9 = Chellman|bibcode = 2015Natur.523..543S|pmid=26153860}}. [http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/511310/ Archived copy]</ref>
In 2018, Harvard University researchers suggested the cause was a volcanic eruption in [[Iceland]] that erupted in early 536, however the author of the previous study said to [[Science (journal)|''Science'' magazine]] that the evidence is insufficient to discard the North America hypothesis.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2018/11/why-536-was-worst-year-be-alive|title=Why 536 was ‘the worst year to be alive’|date=2018-11-15|work=Science {{!}} AAAS|access-date=2018-11-16|language=en|df=mdy-all|author=Gibbons, Ann}}</ref>
==Historic consequences== {{main|Late Antique Little Ice Age}} The 536 event and ensuing famine have been suggested as an explanation for the deposition of [[hoard]]s of gold by Scandinavian elites at the end of the [[Migration Period]]. The gold may have been deposited as a sacrifice to appease the gods and get the sunlight back.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Morten Axboe|author-link=Morten Axboe|title=Året 536|journal=Skalk|volume=|issue=4|pages=28–32|year=2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Morten Axboe|author-link=Morten Axboe|title=The year 536 and the Scandinavian gold hoards|journal=[[Medieval Archaeology (journal)|Medieval Archaeology]]|volume=43|pages=186–8|year=1999|url=http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/arch-769-1/ahds/dissemination/pdf/vol43/43_186_188.pdf}}</ref>
The decline of [[Teotihuacán#Collapse|Teotihuacán]], a huge city in [[Mesoamerica]], is also associated with the droughts related to the [[climate change]]s, with signs of civil unrest and famines.
A book written by David Keys speculates that the climate changes may have contributed to various developments, such as the emergence of the [[Plague of Justinian]], the decline of the [[Avars (Carpathians)|Avars]], the migration of [[Mongolia]]n tribes towards the West, the end of the [[Sassanid Empire]], the collapse of the [[Gupta Empire]], the rise of [[Islam]], the expansion of [[Turkic expansion|Turkic]] tribes, and the fall of Teotihuacán.<ref name="Keys, David Patrick 2000"/> In 2000, a [[3BM Television]] production (for [[WNET]] and [[Channel 4|Channel Four]]) capitalized upon Keys' book. The documentary, under the name ''Catastrophe! How the World Changed'', was broadcast in the US as part of [[PBS]]'s ''[[Secrets of the Dead]]'' series. However, Keys and Wohletz' ideas are not widely accepted now. Reviewing Keys' book, the British archaeologist [[Ken Dark]] commented that "much of the apparent evidence presented in the book is highly debatable, based on poor sources or simply incorrect. [...] Nonetheless, both the global scope and the emphasis on the 6th century AD as a time of wide-ranging change are notable, and the book contains some obscure information which will be new to many. However, it fails to demonstrate its central thesis and does not offer a convincing explanation for the many changes discussed".<ref>{{cite journal|first=Ken|last=Dark |author-link=Ken Dark |title=Review of David Keys' ''Catastroph'' |journal=British Archaeology |issue=49|date=November 1999|url=http://www.britarch.ac.uk/ba/ba49/ba49book.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Gunn, Joel D.|title=The Years Without Summer: Tracing A.D. 536 and its Aftermath|series=British Archaeological Reports (BAR) International|publisher=Archaeopress|location=Oxford, England|year=2000|isbn=1-84171-074-1}}</ref>
==See also== *[[1257 Samalas eruption]] *[[Fimbulwinter]] *[[Great Famine of 1315–17]] *[[Kuwae]], a South Pacific volcano that erupted c. 1452/3<ref>{{Cite journal |first1=Chaochao |last1=Gao |first2=Alan |last2=Robock |first3=Stephen |last3=Self |first4=Jeffrey B. |last4=Witter |first5=J. P.|last5=Steffenson|first6=Henrik Brink|last6=Clausen|first7=Marie-Louise|last7=Siggaard-Andersen|first8=Sigfus|last8=Johnsen|first9=Paul A.|last9=Mayewski|first10=Caspar|last10=Ammann |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=111 |issue=D12107 |page=11 |year=2006 |doi=10.1029/2005JD006710 |title=The 1452 or 1453 A.D. Kuwae Eruption Signal Derived from Multiple Ice Core Records: Greatest Volcanic Sulfate Event of the Past 700 Years |url=http://climate.envsci.rutgers.edu/pdf/Kuwae27.pdf |bibcode=2006JGRD..11112107G}}</ref> *[[Minoan eruption]] *[[Year Without a Summer]], 1816

Hughes|year=2007|title= Bristlecone Pine Tree Rings and Volcanic Eruptions Over the Last 5000 Yr|journal=Quaternary Research|volume=67|issue=1|pages=57–68|url=http://media.longnow.org/files/2/Salzer_Hughes_2007.pdf|accessdate= 2010-03-18|doi=10.1016/j.yqres.2006.07.004|bibcode = 2007QuRes..67...57S }} *{{cite book|author=Winchester, Simon|authorlink=Simon Winchester|title=[[Krakatoa: The Day the World Exploded, August 27, 1883]]|publisher=Harper-Collins|location=New York|year=2003|pages=|isbn=0-06-621285-5}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} [[File:Poem by Martin Niemoeller at the the Holocaust memorial in Boston MA.jpg|350px|thumb|Engraving of the poem presented at the [[New England Holocaust Memorial]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]]]] "'''First they came ...'''" is a poem written by the German [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]] pastor [[Martin Niemöller]] (1892–1984). It is about the [[cowardice]] of German intellectuals following the [[Nazi Party|Nazi]]s' rise to power and subsequent [[Purge|purging]] of their chosen targets, group after group. Many variations and adaptations in the spirit of the original have been published in the English language. It deals with themes of [[persecution]], [[Guilt (emotion)|guilt]] and [[Personal responsibility|responsibility]]. ==The text== The best-known versions of the speech are the poems that began circulating by the 1950s.{{cite web|last=Marcuse|first=Harold|title=Martin Niemöller's famous quotation: "First they came for the Communists ... "|url=http://www.history.ucsb.edu/faculty/marcuse/niem.htm|website=University of California at Santa Barbara}} The [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] quotes the following text as one of the many poetic versions of the speech:{{cite encyclopedia |article=Martin Niemöller: "First they came for the Socialists..." |title=Holocaust Encyclopedia |publisher=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum |url=https://encyclopedia.ushmm.org/content/en/article/martin-niemoeller-first-they-came-for-the-socialists |access-date=25 July 2018}}{{cite encyclopedia |article=Martin Niemöller: "First they came for the Socialists..." |title=Holocaust Encyclopedia |publisher=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum |url=https://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10007392 |access-date=25 July 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180723135844/https://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10007392 |archive-date=23 July 2018 |dead-url=no}} This is a different and older article which contains more complete photographs than the new version. {{bquote | First they came for the socialists, and I did not speak out—
{{in5}}Because I was not a socialist. Then they came for the trade unionists, and I did not speak out—
{{in5}}Because I was not a trade unionist. Then they came for the Jews, and I did not speak out—
{{in5}}Because I was not a Jew. Then they came for me—and there was no one left to speak for me.}} Niemöller created multiple versions of the text during his career, but evidence identified by professor [[Harold Marcuse]] at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara|University of California Santa Barbara]] indicates that the Holocaust Memorial Museum version is inaccurate because Niemöller frequently used the word "[[Communism|communists]]" and not "[[Socialism|socialists]]." The substitution of "socialists" for "communists" is an effect of [[anti-communism]], and most ubiquitous in the version that has proliferated in the United States. According to Marcuse, "Niemöller's original argument was premised on naming groups he and his audience would instinctively not care about. The omission of Communists in Washington, and of Jews in Germany, distorts that meaning and should be corrected." Niemöller's earliest speeches, written in 1946, list the Communists, incurable patients, [[Jews]] or [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], and civilians in countries [[German-occupied Europe|occupied]] by [[Nazi Germany]]. In all versions, the impact is carefully built up, by going from the "smallest, most distant" group to the largest, Jewish, group, and then finally to himself as a by then outspoken critic of [[Nazism]]. Niemöller made the cardinal "who cares about them" clear in his speech for the [[Confessing Church]] in [[Frankfurt]] on 6 January 1946, of which this is a partial translation: {{bquote | When Pastor Niemöller was put in a concentration camp we wrote the year 1937; when the concentration camp was opened we wrote the year 1933, and the people who were put in the camps then were '''Communists'''. Who cared about them? We knew it, it was printed in the newspapers. Who raised their voice, maybe the Confessing Church? We thought: Communists, those opponents of religion, those enemies of Christians - "should I be my brother's keeper?" Then they got rid of the '''sick, the so-called incurables'''. - I remember a conversation I had with a person who claimed to be a Christian. He said: Perhaps it's right, these incurably sick people just cost the state money, they are just a burden to themselves and to others. Isn't it best for all concerned if they are taken out of the middle [of society]? -- Only then did the church as such take note. Then we started talking, until our voices were again silenced in public. Can we say, we aren't guilty/responsible? The persecution of the '''Jews''', the way we treated the '''occupied countries''', or the things in Greece, in Poland, in Czechoslovakia or in Holland, that were written in the newspapers I believe, we Confessing-Church-Christians have every reason to say: mea culpa, mea culpa! We can talk ourselves out of it with the excuse that it would have cost me my head if I had spoken out.}} This speech was translated and published in English in 1947, but was later retracted when it was alleged that Niemöller was an early supporter of the Nazis.{{cite web|author=Marcuse, Harold|url= http://www.history.ucsb.edu/faculty/marcuse/projects/niem/Niem1946GuiltHope13-16.htm |title=Of Guilt and Hope|author2= Niemöller, Martin |website=University of California at Santa Barbara}} The "sick, the so-called incurables" were killed in the euthanasia programme "[[Aktion T4]]". A 1955 version of the speech, mentioned in an interview of a German professor quoting Niemöller, lists Communists, socialists, schools, Jews, the press, and the Church. An American version delivered by a congressman in 1968 includes industrialists, who were not persecuted by the Nazis, and omits Communists. In 1976, Niemöller gave the following answer in response to an interview question asking about the origins of the poem. The ''Martin-Niemöller-Stiftung'' ("Martin Niemöller Foundation") considers this the "classical" version of the speech: {{bquote| There were no minutes or copy of what I said, and it may be that I formulated it differently. But the idea was anyhow: The '''Communists''', we still let that happen calmly; and the '''trade unions''', we also let that happen; and we even let the '''Social Democrats''' happen. All of that was not our affair. The Church did not concern itself with politics at all at that time, and it shouldn't have anything do with them either. In the Confessing Church we didn't want to represent any political resistance ''per se'', but we wanted to determine for the Church that that was not right, and that it should not become right in the Church, that's why already in '33, when we created the pastors' emergency federation ([[Pfarrernotbund]]), we put as the 4th point in the founding charter: If an offensive is made against ministers and they are simply ousted as ministers, because they are of '''Jewish lineage''' (Judenstämmlinge) or something like that, then we can only say as a Church: No. And that was then the 4th point in the obligation, and that was probably the first contra-anti-Semitic pronouncement coming from the Protestant Church.{{cite web|url=http://martin-niemoeller-stiftung.de/martin-niemoeller/was-sagte-niemoeller-wirklich |title=Was sagte Niemöller wirklich?|author=Niemöller, Martin|website=Martin Niemöller Foundation}}}} [[File:Martin Niemöller (1952).jpg|left|thumb|215px|Niemöller at [[The Hague]]'s [[Grote of Sint-Jacobskerk (The Hague)|Grote of Sint-Jacobskerk]] in May 1952]] ==Author== {{main|Martin Niemöller}} Martin Niemöller was a German Lutheran pastor and theologian born in [[Lippstadt]], Germany, in 1892. Niemöller was an [[Anti-communism|anti-Communist]] and supported [[Adolf Hitler]]'s rise to power at first. But when Hitler insisted on the supremacy of the state over religion, Niemöller became disillusioned. He became the leader of a group of German clergymen opposed to Hitler. In 1937 he was arrested and eventually confined in [[Sachsenhausen concentration camp|Sachsenhausen]] and [[Dachau concentration camp|Dachau]]. He was released in 1945 by the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]]. He continued his career in Germany as a clergyman and as a leading voice of penance and reconciliation for the German people after [[World War II]]. His statement, sometimes presented as a poem, is well-known, frequently quoted, and is a popular model for describing the dangers of [[political apathy]]. ==Origin== The statement was published in a book by [[Milton Mayer]], ''They Thought They Were Free'' (1955), based on interviews he had conducted in Germany several years earlier. The quotation was circulated by civil rights activists and educators in the United States in the late 1950s. Some research traces the text to several speeches given by Niemöller in 1946. [[File:US Navy 090427-N-0995C-012 Lt. Dennis Kelly reads an excerpt of Reverend Martin Niemoller's poem, First they came..jpg|thumb|Lt. Dennis Kelly reads an excerpt of Niemöller's poem during a Holocaust Days of Remembrance Observance service in [[Pearl Harbor]]; 27 April 2009]] Nonetheless, the wording remains controversial, both in terms of its provenance, and the substance and order of the groups that are mentioned in its many versions. While Niemöller's published 1946 speeches mention Communists, the incurably ill, Jews or [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] (depending on which speech), and people in occupied countries, the 1955 text, a paraphrase by a German professor in an interview, lists communists, socialists, "the schools, the press, the Jews, and so on", and ends with "the Church". Based on the explanation given by Niemöller himself in 1976, this refers to the German Protestant ('Evangelische') Church, and not to the German Catholic Church. However, as claimed by [[Richard John Neuhaus]] in the November 2001 issue of ''[[First Things]]'', when "asked in 1971 about the correct version of the quote, Niemöller said he was not quite sure when he had said the famous words but, if people insist upon citing them, he preferred a version that listed 'the Communists', 'the trade unionists', 'the Jews', and 'me'."{{cite web|author=Neuhaus, Richard John Neuhaus|url=http://www.firstthings.com/article/2001/11/september-before-and-after|title=September 11-Before and After|publisher=First Things|accessdate=19 June 2014}} However, historian [[Harold Marcuse]] could not verify that interview. Rather, he found a 1976 interview in which Niemöller referred to a 1974 discussion with the general bishop of the [[Lutheran Church of Slovakia]].{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} ==Usages== At the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] in Washington, D.C., the quotation is on display in a variation that substitutes "Socialists" for "Communists". The Holocaust Museum website has a discussion of the history of the quotation.{{cite web|url=http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10007392|author=Niemöller, Martin |title=First they came for the Socialists…|website=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|accessdate=5 February 2011}} A version of the poem is on display at the Holocaust memorial [[Yad Vashem]] in [[Jerusalem]]. The poem is also presented at the [[Virginia Holocaust Museum]] in [[Richmond, Virginia]], the [[New England Holocaust Memorial]] in [[Boston|Boston, Massachusetts]], the [[Florida Holocaust Museum]] in [[St. Petersburg, Florida]], and the Illinois Holocaust Memorial in [[Skokie, Illinois]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Germany}} *[[After Saturday Comes Sunday]] *''[[And Then They Came for Me]]'' *[[Creeping normality]] *[[Democratic backsliding]] *[[Foot-in-the-door technique]] *[[New England Holocaust Memorial]] *"[[Not My Business]]" *[[The Hangman (poem)|"The Hangman" (poem)]] *[[Slippery slope]] *''[[Then They Came for Me]]: A Family's Story of Love, Captivity, and Survival'' ==References== '''Notes''' {{Reflist}} '''Further reading''' * {{cite news|url= http://www.nybooks.com/articles/1971/01/07/an-open-letter-to-my-sister-miss-angela-davis/|title=Open Letter to my Sister, Angela Davis|first=|date=7 January 1971|work= New York Review of Books|access-date=|via=|author=[[James Baldwin|Baldwin, James]]}} Quotation: "If they come for me in the morning, they will come for you in the night." * {{cite book|author=[[Angela Davis|Davis, Angela Y.]]|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/744206.If_They_Come_in_the_Morning|title=If They Come in the Morning: Voices of Resistance |date=1971|publisher=The Third Press|isbn=9780893880224}} * {{citation |date=2003 |author=Stein, Leo |authorlink=Leo Stein |title=They Came for Niemoeller: The Nazi War Against Religion |place=Gretna, Louisiana |publisher=Pelican Publishing Co |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F42NymDVHs8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=martin+niem%C3%B6ller&source=bl&ots=daOWixcXUQ&sig=jh2uo_oyYc57hZHp-yZwMaOqweo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zU41UPTsG6qimQW2nICYBw&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAQ |postscript=  First published 1942 by Fleming H. Revell Co. |isbn=1-58980-063-X |accessdate=22 August 2012}} ==External links== *{{wikiquote-inline|Martin Niemöller}} *{{commonscat-inline|First_they_came_...}} {{DEFAULTSORT:First They Came...}} [[Category:German poems]] [[Category:Poems about the Holocaust]] [[Category:Opposition to antisemitism in Germany]] [[Category:Anti-communism]] [[Category:Crowd psychology]] [[Category:Political and cultural purges]]

{{Good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox flag | Name = South Africa | Article = | Image = Flag of South Africa (1928-1994).svg | Alt = | Noborder = <!-- Leave blank for rectangular flag; for non-rectangular flag, type "no". --> | Nickname = | Morenicks = | Use = <!-- Required for |Symbol --> | Symbol = | Proportion = 2:3 | Adoption = {{start date and age|1928|05|31|df=yes}} | Relinquished = {{Start date and age|1994|04|20|df=y}} | Design = {{FIAV|historical}} Three horizontal bands of orange, white and blue with three small [[flag]]s (the [[Flag of the United Kingdom|Union Jack]] to the left, the vertical version of the [[flag of the Orange Free State]] in the centre and the [[flag of the South African Republic]] to the right) centered on the white band. | Designer = }}
The '''flag of South Africa from 1928 to 1994''' was used by the [[Union of South Africa]] and its successor state, the [[South Africa|Republic of South Africa]] until 1994. It was also used in [[South-West Africa]] (now [[Namibia]]) when the territory was under South African rule. Based on the Dutch [[Prince's Flag]], it contained the [[flag of the United Kingdom]], the [[flag of the Orange Free State]] and the [[flag of the South African Republic]] in the centre.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2015/06/economist-explains-17 |title=How an old Dutch flag became a racist symbol |work=The Economist |date=22 June 2015 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> A nickname for the flag was ''Oranje, Blanje, Blou'' ([[Afrikaans]] for: "orange, white, blue").<ref name=stat />
It was adopted in 1928 by an act of [[Parliament of South Africa|Parliament]] from the first [[Afrikaners|Afrikaner]] majority government. In [[1948]], after their election victory, the [[National_Party_(South_Africa)|National Party]] unsuccessfully tried to amend the flag design to remove what they called the “Blood Stain" (the flag of the United Kingdom).<ref>{{cite web|author=Peter Dickens |url=https://samilhistory.com/2017/03/15/the-inconvenient-and-unknown-history-of-south-africas-national-flags/ |title=The inconvenient and unknown history of South Africa’s national flags |work=The Observation Post |date=15 March 2017 |accessdate=27 September 2018}}</ref> In 1968 Prime Minister [[John Vorster]] proposed the adoption of a new flag in 1971 to commemorate the tenth anniversary of the declaration of South Africa as an independent republic. Vorster's idea did not gain Parliamentary support and the flag change never happened. As such this flag was used during the entirety of the [[apartheid]] era as well, leading to it being labeled the "Apartheid flag".<ref>{{cite web|author=Peter Dickens |url=https://samilhistory.com/2017/03/15/the-inconvenient-and-unknown-history-of-south-africas-national-flags/ |title=The inconvenient and unknown history of South Africa’s national flags |work=The Observation Post |date=15 March 2017 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|quote= Lots of OLD SOUTH AFRICAN FLAGS -- the blue, white and orange apartheid flag -- make a defiant statement against the NEW SOUTH AFRICAN FLAGS ringing the stadium.|url=https://www.imsdb.com/scripts/Invictus.html|access-date=30 October 2018|first=Anthony|last=Peckham|date=22 May 2007|title=INVICTUS (aka 'The Human Factor')}}</ref> It was replaced by the current [[flag of South Africa]] in 1994 with the commencement of the republic's [[South African Constitution of 1993|transitional constitution]] and the [[end of apartheid]].
Following its retirement in 1994 the flag has been controversial within South Africa, with some people viewing it as historic and a symbol of Afrikaner heritage while others view it as a symbol of apartheid and of [[Baasskap|white supremacy]].
== Adoption == [[file:Red Ensign of South Africa (1912-1928).svg|thumb|The South African "Red Ensign" used unofficially until 1928; it continued being used sparsely in limited contexts until the early 1950s.]] {{multiple image |image1=Flag of South Africa (1928–1982).svg |image2=Flag of South Africa (1982–1994).svg |caption1=The flag using a darker shade of "Union" blue common before the early 1980s. |caption2=The flag using a lighter shade of "Solway" blue as specified by the South African government in 1982. }} Before 31 May 1928 the only flag that had official status in the [[Union of South Africa]] was the United Kingdom's [[Union Jack]] as South Africa was part of the [[British Empire]]. The [[South Africa Red Ensign]] was used as an unofficial flag. In 1925, discussion rose about creating a new flag for South Africa as many descendants of [[Boers]] found the Union Jack unacceptable after the [[Boer War]].<ref name=crw /> In 1926 the [[Balfour Declaration of 1926|Balfour Declaration]] granted South Africa legislative autonomy, opening the possibility of a new flag. British settlers wanted the Union Jack in the new flag as part of the [[British Empire]] while the [[Afrikaner]]s did not. A compromise was reached whereby the new flag would consist of the Prince's Flag as this was the first flag raised on South Africa and a badge of the Union Jack in the centre with the flags of the [[Orange Free State]] and the [[South African Republic]].<ref name=crw /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?56323-1/south-african-election-special-2|title=South African Election Special, 2|website=C-SPAN.org}}</ref> The Union Jack was mirrored in the new flag with [[Union Jack#Flying|the hoist on the right]] so that it did not take precedence over the others.<ref name=crw>{{cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/za_old.html |title=South Africa (1928–1994) |publisher=[[Flags of the World]] |date= |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> This was denounced by [[Daniel François Malan|D. F. Malan]], then the South African [[Minister_of_Home_Affairs_(South_Africa)|Minister of Home Affairs]], who described the group of miniature flags "a scab... which will one day fall off".<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6ihVD5RkUIQC&dq=%22Malan%22+%22scab%22+%22flag%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+%22scab%22+ ''South African Tragedy: The Life and Times of Jan Hofmeyr''], [[Alan Paton]], [[Charles Scribner's Sons]], 1966, page 102</ref>
In 1927, the Afrikaner majority [[Parliament of South Africa]] passed the Union Nationality & Flag Act, which stated that the Union Jack and the new Flag of the Union of South Africa were to have equal status as the flag of South Africa. The act came into force in 1928 when both flags were raised over the [[Houses of Parliament, Cape Town]] and the [[Union Buildings]] in Pretoria <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nelsonmandela.org/omalley/index.php/site/q/03lv01538/04lv01646/05lv01769.htm |title=1927. Union Nationality & Flag Act |publisher=The O'Malley Archives |date= |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> This dual status was ended in 1957 with the passing of the Flags Amendment Act which declared that the union flag would be the sole flag of South Africa with the act also declaring that "[[Die Stem van Suid-Afrika]]" would be the country's sole anthem and dropping "[[God Save the Queen]]".<ref name=crw /> [[File:Flag of South Africa 1928-1994, small flags.svg|right|thumb|The flags of the UK, Orange Free State and South African Republic, as arranged in the centre of the national flag]] When South Africa became a republic in 1961, the flag remained the same. The Afrikaner voting majority disliked the flag retaining the Union Jack in the centre. Repeated calls were made for it to be removed or for a new flag but no action was taken by the ruling [[National Party (South Africa)|National Party]] until 1968. [[B. J. Vorster]] convened a commission in that year to create a new flag in time for the 10th anniversary of South Africa's declaration of independence in 1971, but no changes were eventually made.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4eg9AAAAIBAJ&sjid=oUgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2838,2158422&dq=south+africa+change+flag+1971&hl=en|title=Lord Graham quits Smith Cabinet as right-wing anger grows|p=1, 18|work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Glasgow Herald]]|date=12 September 1968|volume=186|edition=197|accessdate=24 November 2017}}</ref> The flag was treated with respect by Afrikaners with daily [[flag salute]]s in schools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/opinionista/2013-12-10-my-old-south-african-flag/#.Vtc9vczcvIU|first=Ivo|last=Vegter |title=My old South African Flag |publisher=Daily Maverick |date=10 December 2013 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> It was also used as part of celebrations of the inauguration of the [[State President of South Africa|State President]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-09-21/news/mn-934_1_south-africa-s-flag |title=De Klerk Sworn In, Pledges S. African Reforms |work=Los Angeles Times |date=21 September 1989 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref>
The flag even had an [[Flag anthem|ode dedicated to it]], "[[:af:Ons eie vlag|Vlaglied]]" ({{Lang-en|"Flag Song"}}),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=34C81-sbDAY|title=Flag anthem of South Africa(1961-1994): "Vlaglied"|access-date=1 November 2018|first=|last=TheKhanate|date=13 June 2016|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref name="vlaglied">{{cite web|url=https://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/za-song.html|title=South Africa - flag songs|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=1 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.za/sites/default/files/Act%209%20of%201974.pdf|title='Vlaglied' Copyright Act, 1974|location=South Africa|access-date=2 November 2018|date=1974|publisher=Republic of South Africa}}</ref> written by [[Cornelis Jacobus Langenhoven]]<ref name="vlaglied"/> and composed by [[:af:F.J. Joubert|F.J. Joubert]].<ref name="vlaglied"/><ref>http://www.wipo.int/edocs/lexdocs/laws/en/za/za041en.pdf</ref>
Due to variances in manufacturing, many flags were manufactured with their blue a dark shade akin to that found on the flag of the UK as many early flags were made in the UK. Because of this discrepancy, in 1982, the South African government specified that "Solway blue", a lighter shade of blue, be used on the flags as was originally intended.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180608104227/http://www.savaflags.org.za/spec/South+Africa+-+National+1928-1994+sheet+2.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=8 June 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180608104803/http://www.savaflags.org.za/spec/South+Africa+-+National+1928-1994+-+sheet+1.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=8 June 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
The flag was featured on the cantons of the flags of government agencies such the military, prisons service, and police.<ref name="crwflags.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/za-polic.html|title=South African Police Service|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> After the flag was retired in 1994, the new South African flag replaced it on those flags' cantons.<ref name="crwflags.com"/>
== Opposition == Despite the flag's origins and adoption pre-dating the National Party's ascension to power by twenty years, the flag gradually became associated with the [[apartheid]] regime. Movements like the [[Black Sash]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.photius.com/countries/south_africa/society/south_africa_society_women_and_apartheid.html |title=South Africa Women and Apartheid |publisher=Photius.com |date= |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> and [[Umkhonto we Sizwe]]<ref name=prot /> started protesting against it with their own symbols. Often the flag of South Africa would be removed from public display and replaced with the banned [[ANC flag]].<ref name=prot>{{cite book | first =Gail | last =Gerhart | title =From Protest to Challenge: A Documentary History of African Politics in South Africa, 1882-1990.| publisher = Indiana University Press | edition = | year = 2010 | isbn = 0253354226 | page = 516}}</ref> The flag would also be the subject of public burnings during [[Internal resistance to South African apartheid|anti-apartheid]] protests.<ref>{{cite web|first=Craig |last=Jungwirth|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V105/N15/rally.15n.html|title=Police arrest nine in protest march |publisher=The Tech|date=5 April 1985 |accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/african-national-congress-supporters-set-a-south-african-news-photo/167948014#african-national-congress-supporters-set-a-south-african-flag-on-fire-picture-id167948014|title=African National Congress (ANC) supporters set a South African flag on fire 14 April 1993 during a commemoration service for South African Communist Party (SACP) chief Chris Hani|publisher=}}</ref>
After 1989, [[F. W. de Klerk]] became state president and immediately unbanned the [[African National Congress]] (ANC) and released their leader [[Nelson Mandela]] from prison. De Klerk instigated [[negotiations to end apartheid in South Africa]] with Mandela's ANC. One of the ANC's demands was that the flag gradually decrease in usage in South African life and that a new flag be created, as black South Africans associated the current one with apartheid and [[Afrikaner nationalism]].<ref>{{cite book | first =Sakhela | last =Buhlungu | title =State of the Nation: South Africa 2007| publisher = A&C Black | edition = | year = 1997 | isbn = 0718500725 | page = 414}}</ref>
The negotiations led to the [[South African apartheid referendum, 1992]] where voters approved the ending of apartheid. The referendum decision resulted in the [[World Rugby|International Rugby Board]] allowing the [[South Africa national rugby union team]] to play test matches again. The ANC agreed to endorse the team on the provision that the flag not be used. During the [[1992 South Africa vs New Zealand rugby union match|return test]], the [[Conservative Party (South Africa)|Conservative Party]] handed out numerous flags to the majority white crowd as a symbol of defiance against the ANC.<ref>{{cite book | first =David Ross | last =Black | title =Rugby and the South African Nation| publisher = Manchester University Press | edition = | year = 1998 | isbn = 0719049326 |page=115 }}</ref> At the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] in [[Barcelona]], the [[South Africa at the 1992 Summer Olympics|South African team]] performed under a specially designed flag for the [[South African Sports Confederation and Olympic Committee|National Olympic Committee of South Africa]], although white South African spectators at the games waved the then national flag, despite attempts by officials to stop them.<ref>{{cite book|first=James |last=Larson|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U_u73VtZcJIC&lpg=PA228&ots=9sYdihq3Ss&dq=south%20africa%20olympics%201992%20flag&pg=PA228#v=onepage&q=south%20africa%20olympics%201992%20flag&f=true |title=''Television in the Olympics'' |isbn=0861965388 |year=1995 |page=228}}</ref> [[File:Flag of South Africa.svg|thumb|The post-1994 flag of South Africa]] In 1994 the State Herald of South Africa, [[Fred Brownell]], was approached to design a new national flag for South Africa to replace the flag in time for the first elections after apartheid. He designed the new flag of South Africa with a combination of the old flag and the colours of the ANC flag. <ref name=brown /> The new flag design was approved personally by both de Klerk and Mandela before being unanimously approved by the [[Transitional Executive Council (South Africa)|Transitional Executive Council]] on 15 March 1994. De Klerk made the public proclamation of the replacement of the old flag on 20 April, seven days before the [[South African general election, 1994|1994 South African general election]] on 27 April 1994.<ref name=brown>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-27155475 |title=Fred Brownell: The man who made South Africa's flag |publisher=BBC News |date=27 April 2014 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> When the flag was lowered for the last time at the parliament building in Cape Town, onlookers approvingly shouted "Down, down!" as it was removed.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4226057.html|title=Unity Flag Shows Its Colors|date=27 April 1994|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sed-dqbZgkc|title=Raising of the New South African Flag|first=|last=Antonio Coppola|date=24 May 2018|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
== After 1994 == Following its official retirement as the flag of South Africa, the flag was adopted by some white South Africans as being a symbol of Afrikaner heritage and history.<ref name=stat>{{cite web|last=Merten |first=Marianne |url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2015-04-13-post-statue-sa-what-will-be-left-when-the-toppling-is-done/#.Vtgxv8zcvIU |title=Post-Statue SA: What will be left when the toppling is done? |work=Daily Maverick |date=13 April 2015 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> Many South Africans still view it as a symbol of apartheid, and therefore have strongly discouraged its use.<ref>{{cite book | first =Christi | last =Van der Westhuizen |title =White Power & the Rise and Fall of the National Party| publisher = Zebra Press | edition = | year = 2007 | isbn = 1770073051 |page=326 }}</ref> Despite the negative associations, it was never banned by the [[Government of South Africa]] post-1994 and the right to display it in South Africa is protected under [[Chapter Two of the Constitution of South Africa]] as an expression of free speech.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Old-flag-still-legal-20091209 |title=Old flag still legal |publisher=News24.com |date=9 December 2009 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> In the 21st century, usage of the old South African flag experienced use of as a symbol by [[white supremacists]] not just in South Africa but worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gettyimages.com/license/98278021|title=South Africans supporting the white supremacist Afrikaner Resistance...|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Josh Sanburn |url=http://time.com/3927339/dylann-roof-charleston-shooting-flags/ |title=Dylann Roof Wears Flag Linked to White Supremacy Groups |work=Time |date=18 June 2015|accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> A particular awareness of this followed the [[Charleston church shooting|shooting at a Charleston, South Carolina black church]] in 2015, as the suspect [[Dylann Roof]] had previously been pictured wearing a jacket with the flag and the [[flag of Rhodesia]] on it.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nick Baumann |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/06/18/dylann-roof-rhodesian-flag_n_7616752.html |title=Dylann Roof Had A Rhodesian Flag On His Jacket - Here's What That Tells Us |work=The Huffington Post |date= |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> This association with apartheid and racism often led to calls for the flags that were used in a historical context, to be removed from display. An example of this is [[Cooma]], Australia, where it is flown to commemorate South African workers in the [[Snowy Mountains Scheme]] alongside the [[Canadian Red Ensign]], [[Flag_of_the_United_States#Historical_progression_of_designs|49 star US flag]], and other flags from 1959 when the Avenue was dedicated.<ref>{{cite web|last=Beech |first=Alexandra |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-08-05/south-african-flag-apartheid-era-cooma-avenue-of-flags/6672314 |title=South Africa's apartheid-era flag to keep flying at Cooma's Avenue of Flags: Mayor |publisher=ABC News |date=5 August 2015 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Old flag of South Africa.jpg|thumb|The flag at the Castle of Good Hope in 2006]] The flag has also been used as a symbol of protest post-1994.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/elmien-du-plessis/the-shadow-of-the-oranje-blanje-blou-at-blackmonday_a_23267048/|title=The Shadow Of The Oranje Blanje Blou At #BlackMonday|date=7 November 2017|publisher=}}</ref> In 2005, a statue of King Makhado was vandalised in [[Louis Trichardt]] with the colours of the flag as a protest against a proposal to change the name of the town to Makhado.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Kings-statue-vandalised-20050914 |title=King's statue vandalised |publisher=News24.com |date=14 September 2005 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> Some South Africans in the 21st century started to fly the flag as a protest against what they perceived as the failure of the ANC to make progress in governing South Africa as a democracy.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kiva |first=Mpumi |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/western-cape/why-we-fly-old-flag-at-our-cape-home-1831280 |title='Why we fly old flag at our Cape home' |publisher=IOL |date=13 March 2015 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref>
At [[Cape Town]]'s [[Castle of Good Hope]], the flag was flown from the castle alongside the Union Jack, [[flag of the Netherlands]] and the current flag of South Africa to display the powers that ruled South Africa through history. In 1994 it was agreed that they would remain on the castle parapet as historical reference. However, in 2012 following complaints from the ANC member of parliament [[Nomfunelo Mabedla]], all the flags were removed from the parapet apart from the current flag of South Africa and the removed flags were placed in the castle's museum.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.iol.co.za/capetimes/row-erupts-over-castle-flags-1433609 |title=Row erupts over Castle flags |publisher=IOL |date=30 November 2012 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref>
In 2008, the flag was mistakenly put on posters in Ghana advertising that year's [[Africa Cup of Nations]], sparking outrage in South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7235415.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Africa - Apartheid flag gaffe sparks row|date=6 January 2018|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180106041257/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7235415.stm|archivedate=6 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Ghana-poster-an-embarrassment-to-SA-139026|title=Ghana poster an 'embarrassment' to SA - General News|date=10 February 2008|access-date=6 January 2018|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180106042024/https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Ghana-poster-an-embarrassment-to-SA-139026|archivedate=6 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

{{About|Global Trade Watch (USA)|Global Trade Watch (Australia)|Global Trade Watch (Australia)}} {{Infobox organization | name = | logo = | Non-profit_type = [[Nonprofit organization]] | founded_date = 1995 | location = [[Washington D.C.]], United States | key_people = [[Lori Wallach]] | type = Consumer advocacy non-profit | area_served = Global | focus = [[International Trade]] | method = [[Research]], [[lobbying]], litigation and appeals, media attention, direct-appeal campaigns | revenue = $15.468 million<ref name="Public Citizen Annual Report">{{cite web|title=Public Citizen Annual Report|url=http://www.citizen.org/documents/PC2013.pdf|publisher=Public Citizen|accessdate=28 May 2014}}</ref> | homepage = http://www.citizen.org/trade }}
'''Global Trade Watch''' (GTW) was founded by [[Lori Wallach]] in 1995 as a division of the U.S.-based non-profit consumer advocacy organization, [[Public Citizen]], that monitors the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) and other [[trade agreements]] such as the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA) and the [[Central America Free Trade Agreement]] (CAFTA), as well as ongoing negotiations over trade agreements such as the [[Trans-Pacific Partnership]] (TPP) and the [[Trans-Atlantic Free Trade Agreement]] (TAFTA / TTIP). Like Public Citizen in general, GTW advocates for a greater public role in international, federal, state and local policy-making, and for a different set of policies and institutions than those governing the current model of [[globalization]].
Global Trade Watch holds a position on the executive board on the [[Citizens Trade Campaign]] and belongs to Our World Is Not For Sale.
==Founding== [[Lori Wallach]], GTW's Director and Founder was described as "[[Ralph Nader]] with a sense of humor" in a ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' profile, dubbed "the Trade Debate's Guerrilla Warrior" by the ''[[National Journal]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jrn.columbia.edu/events/reuters/2000-02-09.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-08-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060814182855/http://www.jrn.columbia.edu/events/reuters/2000-02-09.asp |archivedate=2006-08-14 |df= }}</ref> the "[[Madame Defarge]] of Seattle" by the [[Institute for International Economics]],<ref>[http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2633/is_4_14/ai_64564019/print]</ref> and "a key player in Washington debates on trade policy" by [[The Nation]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.commondreams.org/views06/0612-33.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-08-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060826001630/http://www.commondreams.org/views06/0612-33.htm |archivedate=2006-08-26 |df= }}</ref> Wallach is a graduate of [[Harvard University]] and previously worked for Public Citizen as a lobbyist for food safety improvements.
==Archives== * [http://digital.lib.washington.edu/findingaids/view?docId=WTO1999SeattleProtest5177.xml World Trade Organization 1999 Seattle Ministerial Conference Protest Collection] 1993-2000. 43.63 cubic feet. At the [http://www.lib.washington.edu/specialcoll/laws Labor Archives of Washington, University of Washington Libraries Special Collections].
==References== {{reflist}} * [https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/economy/july-dec05/cafta_7-27.html Ray Suarez, "The Battle Over CAFTA," PBS Online NewsHour, July 27, 2005.] * [http://www.thenation.com/blogs/notion?bid=15&pid=105865 William Greider, "Whither the WTO," The Nation, July 26, 2006.] * [http://www.rollcall.com/issues/52_12/news/14483-1.html Kate Ackley, "Trade Lobbyists: Agenda Doesn’t Stop With Doha," Roll Call, July 26, 2006.] * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/07/25/AR2006072501621.html Paul Blustein, "Failed Trade Talks Usher in Uncertainty, WTO System Could Weaken After Breakdown Puts Globalization on Unclear Path," Washington Post, July 26, 2006.]
