[[File:Paasikivi ja Voroshilov.jpg|thumb|right|250px|President of Finland [[J.K. Paasikivi]] with Kliment Voroshilov.]] [[File:Voroshilov, Khrushchev, Kekkonen.jpeg|thumb|right|250px|[[Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet]], Marshal [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|General Secretary of the Central Committee]] of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|CPSU]] Nikita Khrushchev, and [[President of Finland]] Urho Kekkonen meeting in Moscow in November 1960.]] {{refimprove|date=September 2014}} The '''Paasikivi-Kekkonen doctrine ''' refers to a [[foreign policy doctrine]] established by [[Finnish President]] [[Juho Kusti Paasikivi]] and continued by his successor [[Urho Kekkonen]], aimed at [[Finland]]'s survival as an independent [[sovereignty|sovereign]], [[democracy|democratic]], and [[capitalism|capitalist]] [[country]] in the immediate proximity of the [[Soviet Union]].
The principal architect of Finland's postwar [[Foreign relations of Finland|foreign policy]] of [[neutral country|neutrality]] was [[Juho Kusti Paasikivi]], who was president from 1946 to 1956.<ref name=publico>{{cite web |url=http://www.publico.es/internacional/finlandia-crisis-otros-anoran.html |title=Finlandia, la 'crisis' que otros añoran |access-date=November 8, 2017 |last=Ferrero |first=Ángel |date=June 4, 2016 |work=Publico |publisher= |location= |language=spanish |quote= }}</ref> [[Urho Kekkonen]], president from 1956 until 1981, further developed this policy, stressing that Finland should be an active rather than a passive neutral.
== Background == Finland and the Soviet Union signed the [[Paris Peace Treaty]] in February 1947, which in addition to the concessions of the [[Moscow Peace Treaty]] provided for: * Limiting the size of [[Finnish Defence Forces|Finland's defense forces]], * Cession to the Soviet Union of the [[Pechengsky District|Petsamo]] area on the [[Arctic]] coast, * Lease of the [[Porkkala]] [[peninsula]] off Helsinki to the Soviets for use as a [[naval base]] for 50 years (it was returned ahead of schedule in 1956), * Free transit access to this area across Finnish territory, and * [[War reparations]] to the Soviet Union decided to 300 million gold dollars (amounting to an estimated 570 million [[U.S. dollar]]s in 1952, the year the payments ended).
== Realization == In April 1948, Finland signed an [[Finno-Soviet Treaty of 1948|Agreement of Friendship, Cooperation, and Mutual Assistance]] with the Soviet Union.<ref name=Britannica>{{cite web |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Finland/The-postwar-period |title=Finland - The postwar period |access-date=November 8, 2017 |last= |first= |date= |work= |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica |location=London |language= |quote= }}</ref> Under this mutual assistance pact, Finland was obligated, with the aid of the Soviet Union, if necessary, to resist armed attacks by "Germany or its allies" (i.e., [[NATO]]) against Finland or against the Soviet Union ''through'' Finland. At the same time, the agreement recognized Finland's desire to remain outside great-power conflicts. This agreement was renewed for 20 years in 1955, in 1970, and again in 1983.<ref name=publico /> This allowed Finland to retain independence in internal affairs, e.g. a multiparty parliamentary system, and not to join the [[Eastern Bloc]]. However, joining NATO or other overt alliance with the West was out of question<ref name=Britannica /> and foreign policy was often limited.
== Criticism == Contemporary Finns often criticized the Paasikivi-Kekkonen doctrine as tending towards a "liturgy" of good relations. Both countries were militarily prepared. However, international trade was active, in the framework of [[bilateral trade]]. Furthermore, the policy was heavily tied to the person of President Kekkonen, who consequently exploited his position as a "guarantor of Soviet relations" against political opponents. Outright censorship was employed for films and works considered explicitly anti-Soviet (e.g. ''[[The Manchurian Candidate (1962 film)|The Manchurian Candidate]]''), although political freedoms were not otherwise coercively limited.
Later criticism has included the following points: * The Soviet Union did not consider Finland a neutral country, but "striving to be neutral". Although Kekkonen was largely successful in retaining sovereign power over affairs in Finland, Finland's position on international affairs, such as the invasion of Czechoslovakia, was often ambiguous or Soviet-friendly. The [[1977 Aeroflot Tupolev Tu-134 hijacking|1977 hijacking of a Soviet airliner]] further exemplifies this; the undue influence of the Soviet ambassador, who would storm a government meeting to make demands, shows that the Finnish government had trouble fending off Soviet interference.<ref name="Tiilikainen">Tiilikainen, Heikki. ''Kylmän sodan kujanjuoksu.''</ref> The Soviet Union had an unusually large diplomatic mission in Finland, and Kekkonen communicated with the Soviet Union through the [[KGB]] [[station chief]] rather than by regular diplomatic channels. The Soviets intervened in Finnish politics in various ways, e.g. through the [[Communist Party of Finland]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.loyno.edu/~history/journal/1985-6/botticelli.htm |title=Finland's Relations with the Soviet Union, 1940-1986 |access-date=November 8, 2017 |last=Botticelli |first=Peter |date= |work= |publisher= |location= |language= |quote= }}</ref> and Soviet-friendly contacts in other parties (e.g. Kekkonen's ''K-linja'' in the [[Centre Party (Finland)|Centre Party]]). * The Soviet military kept a separate unit in readiness to invade Helsinki from Tallinn in the case of war. The plans, which were fully up-to-date, were left behind in the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Estonia after Estonia regained independence in 1991. * The policy had little respect in the West. Western foreign policy actors and military personnel either did not know about the policy or assumed it was a failure from the outset. Regarding the former, British military officers were known to have queried how many Soviet troops were in Finland.<ref name="Tiilikainen" /> Regarding the latter, nuclear weapons were trained on targets in Finland, with the assumption that any possible Finnish resistance to a Soviet invasion would be a certain failure. * There was covert cooperation between the Finnish government and Western intelligence agencies. The CIA could fund the anti-Communist [[Social Democratic Party (Finland)|Social Democratic Party]], a major, often government-leading party, though it gradually became unusually pro-Soviet beginning in the late 1960s, with many radical leftists holding influential posts among other such parties. There was also military intelligence cooperation, for instance allowing SIGINT flights to probe the Soviet radar network (according to Pekka Visuri) and providing seismic data to detect Soviet nuclear tests.
== Liquidation == The Finns responded cautiously in 1990–91 to the decline of Soviet power and the USSR's subsequent [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|dissolution]]. They unilaterally abrogated restrictions imposed by the 1947 and 1948 treaties with the exception of a ban on acquiring [[nuclear weapons]], joined in voicing [[Nordic countries|Nordic]] concerns over the coup against Soviet leader [[Mikhail Gorbachev]], and gave increasing unofficial encouragement to [[Baltic states|Baltic]] independence.
At the same time, by replacing the Soviet-Finnish mutual assistance pact with treaties on general cooperation and trade, Finns put themselves on an equal footing while retaining a friendly bilateral relationship. Finland now is boosting cross-border commercial ties and touting its potential as a commercial gateway to Russia. It has reassured [[Russia]] that it will not raise claims about the [[Karelian question in Finnish politics|formerly Finnish territory]] ceded after the [[Continuation War]] (though a small but vocal minority of the people disagrees), and continues to reaffirm the importance of good bilateral relations.

{{Infobox organization |name = Post-Conflict Research Center |image = Post-Conflict Research Center.png |type = Non-governmental organization |headquarters = [[Sarajevo]] (Bosnia-Herzegovina) |leader_title = President and Co-Founder |leader_name = [[Velma Šarić]] (2010-present) |language = [[English language|English]] and [[Bosnian language|Bosnian]] |formation = 2010 |website = http://p-crc.org/ |purpose = peace building, post-conflict reconciliation }}
The '''Post-Conflict Research Center''' (PCRC) is a Sarajevo-based non-governmental organization, which aims to nurture an enabling environment for sustainable [[peace]] and facilitate the restoration of inter-ethnic relationships in [[Bosnia-Herzegovina]]. PCRC's expertise consists of innovative [[multimedia]] projects and creative educational curricula that engage youth in fostering long-lasting tolerance, mutual understanding, and social activism in the [[Western Balkans]] region.<ref>[http://p-crc.org/ Post-Conflict Research Center]</ref> The Center’s overall mission is to build a robust network empowering youth with transferable skills and resources to spread an all-encompassing culture of peace among the many ethnic groups composing the country. PCRC’s main activities involve [[youth]] and [[Conflict resolution|reconciliation]], [[media freedom]], [[gender]] and peace-building through educational activities, [[storytelling]] and [[investigative journalism]].
== History == The PCRC was established in 2010 by Founder and Executive Director [[Velma Šarić]] and Co-founder and Project Director Leslie Woodward. They first met in Sarajevo when Woodward, a graduate student with substantial experience in strategic peace-building, post-conflict development, and research in [[developing country]] contexts, came to attend a study abroad program course designed by Šarić, an experienced journalist and researcher in the fields of [[sociology]] and [[international law]]. Once Woodward returned to the USA, they both developed projects and wrote grants over [[Skype]] with the goal of setting up an organization dedicated to building peace in Bosnia-Herzegovina.<ref>[http://p-crc.org/our-story/ Post-Conflict Research Center - Our Story]</ref> PCRC today counts 7 staff members, several interns and 40 experts providing valuable insights and guidance to the organization. PCRC brings citizens of Bosnia-Herzegovina together to discuss current cultural and political issues and speak their minds with the aim to strengthen local communities in the country.
== Activities and Projects ==
PCRC’s work revolves around three main areas:<ref>[http://p-crc.org/mission/ Post-Conflict Research Center - Our Mission]</ref> youth and reconciliation – molding positive narratives of inter-ethnic cooperation by applying examples from the past to current models of pro-social behavior; media freedom - challenging the Bosnia’s one-sided [[mainstream]] media coverage by providing a safe space where youth can discuss issues they hold dear to their hearts at the local level; gender and peace building – empowering women to influence gender rights discourses and foster positive social change, especially by aiding victims of wartime [[sexual violence]] to address impunity in Bosnia-Herzegovina.<ref>[http://p-crc.org/strategy/ Post-Conflict Research Center - Strategy]</ref><ref>[http://thelondonpost.net/velma-saric-a-bosnian-with-a-vision/ Velma Saric – Bosnian with vision]</ref>
== Balkan Diskurs == One of the initiatives PCRC works on is [http://www.balkandiskurs.com/en/ Balkan Diskurs], an online platform run by a regional network of young journalists and activists, which aims to address the lack of objective and alternative media. The platform provides a space free from [[censorship]] to publish peoples’ opinions and analyses of current issues in the Western Balkans region.
== Ordinary Heroes == Ordinary Heroes is a [[multimedia]] educational project that uses photos, films and youth workshops to tell the accounts of four post-conflict regions - Bosnia and Herzegovina, [[Rwanda]], [[Cambodia]], and post-[[Holocaust]] [[Europe]], through stories of rescue and courage with the aim to bolstering [[toleration|tolerance]], reconciliation and inter-ethnic cooperation. The project encompasses a documentary series that portrays real-life stories of Bosnian citizens who came to rescue others during the war, workshops engaging local youth and a traveling photographic exhibition. Ordinary Heroes was designed by PCRC to foster social healing and reconciliation among inter-groups in Bosnia-Herzegovina. In 2014, Ordinary Heroes was awarded the Intercultural Innovation Award by the [[United Nations Alliance of Civilizations]] (UNAOC) and the [[BMW]] Group. The award recognizes ground-breaking grassroots projects encouraging intercultural dialogue and contributing to global peace.

[[Image:LogoRigsrevisionen 372DK.gif|thumb|right|240px]] '''Rigsrevisionen''' is the national [[audit]] agency of the [[Kingdom of Denmark]] and an independent institution of the [[Folketing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.dk/Folketinget/Folketingets_institutioner/Rigsrevisionen.aspx|accessdate=2011-04-17|title=Folketinget - Rigsrevisionen}}</ref>
It is responsible for auditing the expenditure of Danish central government, and also [[Public sector|public-sector]] bodies in which the government has an economic interest, such as [[hospital]]s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.regioner.dk/Aktuelt/Nyheder/2010/December/Rigsrevisionen+anerkender+2009+som+et+s%C3%A6rligt+%C3%A5r.aspx|accessdate=2011-04-17|title=Regioner - Rigsrevisionen anerkender 2009 som et særligt år}}</ref> and the [[Danish Security and Intelligence Service]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pet.dk/Kontrol/Rigsrevisionen.aspx|accessdate=2011-04-17|title=PET: Rigsrevisionens kontrol}}</ref>
In July 2011, Rigsrevision made serious criticisms of the [[Royal Danish Navy]]'s finances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://politiken.dk/debat/kroniker/ECE1344734/hvad-skal-vi-med-forsvaret/|accessdate=14 August 2011|title=Hvad skal vi med forsvaret?|date=25 July 2014}}</ref>
Auditing is not limited to narrow financial terms, such as investigating the stability of the banking system;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dr.dk/Nyheder/Penge/2011/01/28/065202.htm|accessdate=2011-04-17|title=Rigsrevisionen kulegraver Finansiel Stabilitet}}</ref> it also checks that public services provide value for taxpayers' money in a more general sense. For instance, in 2011, Rigsrevisionen launched an investigation into the ability of water suppliers and the environment ministry to protect consumers from traces of herbicides in drinking water.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ing.dk/artikel/115997-rigsrevisionen-undersoeger-statens-evne-til-at-passe-paa-drikkevandet|accessdate=2011-04-17|title=Rigsrevisionen undersøger statens evne til at passe på drikkevandet | publisher =Ingeniøren}}</ref>
Rigsrevisionen was part of the Economy ministry from 1971 to 1991.

[[Yawd Serk]] |ideology = [[Shan nationalism]]
[[Separatism]] |clans = |partof = {{flagicon image|Mong Tai Army flag.svg}} [[Mong Tai Army]] |next = {{flagicon image|SSA-S.svg}} [[Shan State Army - South]] |headquarters = [[Homong]], [[Shan State]] |area = [[Shan State]] |strength = |opponents = {{flagicon image|Flag of Myanmar (1974-2010).svg}} [[State Peace and Development Council|Union of Myanmar]] * {{flagicon image|Flag of the Myanmar Armed Forces.svg}} [[Tatmadaw]] |battles = [[Internal conflict in Myanmar]] |website = }} The '''Shan United Revolutionary Army''' ({{lang-my|ရှမ်းပြည်နယ်တပ်ပေါင်းစုတော်လှန်ရေးတပ်မတော်}}; [[Abbreviation|abbreviated]] '''SURA'''), was a [[Shan people|Shan]] [[Insurgency|insurgent group]] in [[Myanmar]] (Burma), led by several drug warlords such as [[Khun Sa]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ucdp.uu.se/gpdatabase/gpcountry.php?id=112®ionSelect=7-Eastern_Asia#,|title=Uppsala Conflict Encyclopedia, Myanmar (Burma)|publisher=|accessdate=29 November 2014}} ==History== The SURA had multiple factions, such as the "Tai Revolutionary Council" led by [[Moh Heng]], a group which would merge in 1985 with Khun Sa's [[Shan United Army]] (SUA){{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/para/sua.htm|title=Shan United Army (SUA) - Mong Tai Army (MTA)|work=GlobalSecurity|accessdate=26 May 2016}} in order to create the [[Mong Tai Army]] with its base of operations in [[Homong]].{{cite web|url=http://factsanddetails.com/southeast-asia/Myanmar/sub5_5g/entry-3078.html|title=Golden Triangle drug Lords: Khun Sa, Lo Hsing Han, Miss Hairy Legs and the Wa State Army|work=Facts and Details|accessdate=26 May 2016}}; [[Bertil Lintner]], in Asia Online; November 1, 2007{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LclscNCTz9oC&pg=PA870&lpg=PA870&dq=%22Shan+State+National+Army%22+MTA&source=bl&ots=ym-nYd0e02&sig=QV59FgiypPy07ZYlP0e6_ZDONgI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=u2MSVJSODc6hugTjjYGwDA&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22Shan%20State%20National%20Army%22%20MTA&f=false|title=''The Far East and Australasia 2003'', p. 870|publisher=|accessdate=29 November 2014}} In 1996 most of its soldiers disarmed, but a group of 800 soldiers were integrated into the newly formed [[Shan State Army - South]] by [[Yawd Serk]]. ==Further reading== * Trevor Wilson (ed.) ''Myanmar's Long Road to National Reconciliation'', Institute of Southeast Asian Studies, 2006, {{ISBN|978-981-230-363-9}}; 981-230-363-4 ==See also== * [[Mong Tai Army]] * [[Opium production in Myanmar]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Insurgent groups in Myanmar}} {{Myanmar-stub}} [[Category:Rebel groups in Myanmar]] [[Category:Shan militia groups]] [[Category:Paramilitary organisations based in Myanmar]]

'''Society of Intercultural Philosophy''' (SIP) ({{lang-de|Gesellschaft für Interkulturelle Philosophie (GIP)}}) is a non-profit association dealing with [[intercultural philosophy]] based in [[Cologne]]. It was founded in 1992 and now has members all over the world. [[Claudia Bickmann]] and [[Georg Stenger]] are the presidents of the society.
==Sources== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120202032836/http://www.bautz.de/yousefi.html – Es geht um Veröffentlichung zum Thema Interkulturelle Philosophie] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20161111113720/http://www.bautz.de/interkulturell.shtml – Es handelt sich um die wissen. Reihe Interkulturelle Bibliothek] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20161113042857/http://www.bautz.de/wege.html – Es handelt sich um eine wissen. Reihe zum Thema Interkulturelle Forschung] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20161113043455/http://www.bautz.de/bausteine.html – Es geht um unterschiedliche Themenfelder der Interkulturalität] *[http://www.wigip.org Wiener Gesellschaft für interkulturelle Philosophie (WiGiP)] *[http://www.polylog.net Polylog - Zeitschrift für Interkulturelles Philosophieren] *[https://www.polylog.org/index-en.htm polylog – Forum for Intercultural Philosophy] *[http://www.yousefi-interkulturell.de/phil.pdf Interkulturelle Philosophie : Struktur – Gegenstand – Aufgabe (PDF; 214 kB)]

[[File:StauningOrChaos.jpg|thumb|right| The election poster with the famous slogan "Stauning or Chaos - Vote Social Democrat"]] '''"Stauning or Chaos"''' ([[Danish language|Danish]] ''Stauning eller Kaos'') is a famous Danish election slogan from the [[Danish Folketing election, 1935|parliamentary election of 1935]], in which [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democrat]] [[Thorvald Stauning]] campaigned for re-election. The Social Democrats won the election winning 68 out of 149 seats, and Stauning continued on to be the second-longest serving [[List of Prime Ministers of Denmark|Prime Minister]] in Danish history.<ref>Henry Conserva. 2006. National Slogans From Around the World. AuthorHouse. [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=DsJu1iboWaIC&oi=fnd&pg=PP2&dq=Stauning+or+chaos&ots=VtT5dCQPZl&sig=xCKvMzbEk0rZltS-5AzNMDdrEq4#v=onepage&q=Stauning&f=false]</ref><ref>Torben Kragh Grodal, Bente Larsen, Iben Thorving Laursen. 2005. Visual Authorship: Creativity And Intentionality In Media. Museum Tusculanum Press. p. 175</ref><ref>Prestige and lack of alternative: Denmark and the United Nations in the making Norbert Götz Scandinavian Journal of History Vol. 29, Iss. 2, 2004</ref><ref>Stauning eller kaos: socialdemokratiet og krisen i trediverne H Sonne - 1974 - H. Reitzel</ref>
The campaign with its warning against "chaos", interpreted as the threat of [[fascism]], is an example of the emotional and activist campaign style used by the major political parties in Denmark in the 1920s and 1930s, often capitalizing on the public fear of the perceived threats of radical ideologies such as fascism and [[communism]].<ref>John T. Lauridsen. 2000. NAZISTISK PLAKATPROPAGANDA I DANMARK 1930-45 En dokumentation. Fund og Forskning, Bind 39 (2000)[http://e-tidsskrifter.dk/ojs/index.php/fundogforskning/article/view/1369/2218] </ref>

{{Infobox War Faction |name=Tigers Militia
نمور الأحرار |war=[[Lebanese civil war]] (1975-1990) |image=[[File:Noumour.jpg]] |caption='''NLP Tigers Militia logo''' (1968-1980) |active=Until 1980 |leaders= [[Naim Berdkan]], [[Dany Chamoun]], [[Dory Chamoun]], [[Georges Araj]], [[Nouhad Chelhot]] |clans=[[Lebanese Front]], [[Lebanese Forces (militia)|Lebanese Forces]] |headquarters=[[Sodeco Square]] ([[Achrafieh]] – [[Beirut]]), [[Safra, Lebanon|Safra]] |areas=[[East Beirut]], [[Mount Lebanon]], [[South Lebanon]] |strength=3,500 fighters |previous=500 fighters |allies=[[Lebanese Army]], [[South Lebanon Army]] (SLA), [[Guardians of the Cedars]] (GoC), [[Army of Free Lebanon]] (AFL), [[Al-Tanzim]], [[Kataeb Regulatory Forces]] (KRF), [[Tyous Team of Commandos]] (TTC), [[Lebanese Forces (militia)|Lebanese Forces]] |opponents=[[Lebanese National Movement]] (LNM), [[Lebanese Arab Army]] (LAA), [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] (PLO), [[Palestine Liberation Army]] (PLA), [[Syrian Army]], [[Lebanese Resistance Regiments|Amal Movement]], [[Al-Mourabitoun]], [[Lebanese Forces (militia)|Lebanese Forces]] }} The '''Tigers Militia''' ([[Arabic Language|Arabic]]: نمور الأحرار, [[Romanization of Arabic|transliterated]]: ''Numūr'' or ''Al-Noumour''), also known as '''NLP Tigers''' or '''Tigers of the Liberals''' ([[Arabic Language|Arabic]]: ''Numur al-Ahrar'') and '''PNL "Lionceaux"''' in [[French language|French]], was the military wing of the [[National Liberal Party (Lebanon)|National Liberal Party]] (NLP) during the [[Lebanese Civil War]]. == Origins == The NLP militia was first raised in October 1968 by [[Camille Chamoun]] at his own home town of Es-Sa'adiyat, originally under the title '''Brigade of the Lebanese Tigers – BLT''' ([[Arabic]]: ''Katibat al-Numur al-Lubnaniyya'') or '''Brigade des Lionceaux Libanais (BLL)''' in [[French language|French]], allegedly taken from his middle name, ''Nimr'' – meaning "Tiger" in Arabic. Initially just 500-men strong,McGowan, Roberts, Abu Khalil, and Scott Mason, ''Lebanon: a country study'' (1989), p. 240. the BLT was organized, trained, and led by the 'defence secretary' of the NLP [[Naim Berdkan]]; after his death in action in January 1976, he was succeeded by [[Dany Chamoun]], Camille Chamoun's younger son. Initially allocated in the NLP party offices' at [[Sodeco Square]] in the Nasra (Nazareth) neighbourhood of the [[Achrafieh]] quarter in Beirut, the Tigers' military HQ was relocated in 1978 to [[Safra, Lebanon|Safra]], a boat marina and tourist beach resort located 25 km north of the Lebanese capital in the [[Keserwan District]], where it remained until the militia's dissolution. == Structure and organization == Under the command of [[Dany Chamoun]], the Tigers had become by 1978 the second largest militia force in the [[Christianity in Lebanon|Christian]] [[Lebanese Front]], and although the Chamouns never achieved with their own militia the same level of organizational efficiency displayed by the rival [[Kataeb Party|Phalange]]' [[Kataeb Regulatory Forces]] militia, they were nonetheless capable of aligning 3,500 men and women, though other sources list a total of 4,000,Makdisi and Sadaka, ''The Lebanese Civil War, 1975-1990'' (2003), p. 44, Table 1: War Period Militias.El-Kazen, ''The Breakdown of the State in Lebanon'' (2000), p. 302. which included civilian recruits and deserters from the [[Lebanese Army]]. However, other unconfirmed sources advance an even higher number, about 15,000.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} Their 500 full-time fighters and 3,000 part-time reservists were organized into [[armoured warfare|armoured]], '[[commando]]', [[infantry]], [[artillery]], [[Signals (military)|signals]], [[medical]], [[logistics]] and [[military police]] branches. Their chain of command was predominantly Maronite, though the rank-and-file were drawn from the [[Maronite Christianity in Lebanon|Maronite]], [[Greek Orthodox Christianity in Lebanon|Greek-Orthodox]], [[Druze in Lebanon|Druze]], and [[Shia Islam in Lebanon|Shi'ite]] militants of the NLP and trained in-country at clandestine facilities; first set up by the NLP in 1966 these training centres were located at [[Naas, Lebanon|Naas]] in the [[Matn District]], [[Es-Saadiyat]] in the [[Iqlim al-Kharrub]] coastal enclave south of [[Beirut]] and at [[Adma wa Dafneh|Adma]] in the northern mountainous [[Keserwan District]]. NLP militia units operated mainly in [[East Beirut]], the [[Jbeil District|Jbeil]], [[Matn District|Matn]] and [[Keserwan District]]s and [[Tripoli, Lebanon|Tripoli]], but also had a presence at [[Zahlé]] in the [[Beqaa valley]], at the south in the Iqlim al-Kharrub, the [[Aley District]] and the [[Jabal Amel]],Deeb, ''The Lebanese Civil War'' (1980), pp. 25-28.Rabinovich, ''The War for Lebanon'' (1989), p. 65. where their local militants – after merging with other Christian, [[Shia Islam in Lebanon|Shia Muslim]] and [[Druze people in Lebanon|Druze]] militias – played a key part in the formation on 21 October 1976 of the Israeli-backed informal "Army for the Defense of South Lebanon" or ADSL ([[French language|French]]: ''Armée de Défense du Liban-Sud'' or ADLS),Hokayem, ''L'armée libanaise pendant la guerre: un instrument du pouvoir du président de la République (1975-1985)'' (2012), p. 43. later to become known as the "Free Lebanese Army" (FLA), the predecessor of the [[South Lebanon Army]] (SLA).[https://histoiredelarmeelibanaise.wordpress.com/2012/06/17/chamussy-rene-chronique-dune-guerre-le-liban-1975-1977-ed-desclee-1978/ Chamussy (René) – Chronique d'une guerre: Le Liban 1975-1977 – éd. Desclée – 1978] ==Weapons and equipment== The Tigers received covert support not only from the [[Lebanese Army]] in the pre-war years, but also from the [[United States]], [[Iran]], [[Jordan]] and [[Egypt]] since 1973, followed by [[Israel]] and [[Syria]] in 1976-77, who provided weapons and heavy equipment. In addition, the collapse of the [[Lebanese Armed Forces]] (LAF) and the [[Internal Security Forces]] (ISF) in January 1976, coupled by the massive influx of Israeli military aid, allowed NLP militia units to re-equip themselves with modern small-arms, sophisticated mobile communications equipment,Jureidini, McLaurin, and Price, ''Military operations in selected Lebanese built-up areas'' (1979), pp. 42-45. and military vehicles seized from LAF barracks and ISF Police stations or supplied by the Israelis. Adittional weapons and other military equipments were procured in the international [[black market]]. ===Small-arms=== [[File:Tigers Militia in Achrafieh, 1978.jpg|alt=Tigers Militia in Achrafieh armed with a Kalashnikov Rifle 1978|thumb|NLP Tigers' militiaman armed with a AKM in [[Achrafieh]], east Beirut, June 1978.]] Tigers' militiamen were provided with a variety of small-arms, including [[Lee-Enfield]] and [[MAS-36 rifle|MAS-36]] [[Bolt action|bolt action rifles]], [[MAT-49]] and [[PPSh-41]] submachine guns, [[M1 carbine|M2]] and [[SIG SG 540|SIG SG 543 carbine]]s, [[MAS-49 rifle|MAS-49]], [[M1 Garand]] (or its Italian-produced copy, the Beretta Model 1952), [[SKS]], [[Beretta BM 59]] and [[M14 rifle|M14]]Huon, ''Un Siècle d'Armement Mondial: Armes à feu d'infanterie de petit calibre, tome 4'' (1981), page unknown. [[semi-automatic rifle]]s, [[Heckler & Koch G3]], [[FN FAL]] (variants included the Israeli-produced 'lightened' [[FN FAL|ROMAT M1953]]), [[M16 rifle|M16A1]], [[SIG SG 540|SIG SG 542]], [[Vz. 58]], [[AK-47]] and [[AKM]] assault rifles (other variants included the [[Zastava M70]], Chinese [[Type 56 assault rifle|Type 56]], Romanian [[Puşcă Automată model 1986|AIM]], Bulgarian AKK/AKKS and former East German MPi assault rifles). Several models of handguns were used, including [[Smith & Wesson Model 10]], [[Smith & Wesson Model 13]], [[Smith & Wesson Model 14]], [[Smith & Wesson Model 15]], [[Smith & Wesson Model 17]] and [[Smith & Wesson Model 19]] revolvers, [[M1911 pistol|Colt M1911A1]], [[TT pistol|Tokarev TT-33]], [[CZ 75]], [[Browning Hi-Power|FN P35]] and [[MAB PA-15 pistol]]s. Squad weapons consisted of [[FM 24/29 light machine gun|Chatellerault FM Mle 1924/29]], [[Bren light machine gun|Bren Mk. I .303 (7.7mm)]], [[MG 34]], [[MG 42]], [[Heckler & Koch HK21]], [[AA-52 machine gun|AA-52]], [[RPD machine gun|RPD]], [[RPK]] and [[FN MAG|FN MAG light machine gun]]s, with heavier [[Besa machine gun|Besa Mark III 7.92mm]], [[M1919 Browning machine gun|Browning M1919A4 .30 Cal]], [[M2 Browning|Browning M2HB .50 Cal]], [[SG-43 Goryunov|SG-43/SGM Goryunov]] and [[DShK]] machine guns being employed as platoon and company weapons. Grenade launchers and portable anti-tank weapons comprised [[M203 grenade launcher]]s, [[Bazooka|88.9mm Instalaza M65]], [[RL-83 Blindicide]], [[M72 LAW]], [[RPG-2]] and [[RPG-7]] [[Anti-tank rocket|rocket launcher]]s, whilst crew-served and indirect fire weapons included [[120-PM-43 mortar|120-PM-43 (M-1943) 120mm heavy mortars]], plus [[B-10 recoilless rifle|B-10 82mm]], [[B-11 recoilless rifle|B-11 107mm]] and [[M40 recoilless rifle|M40A1 106mm]] [[recoilless rifle]]s (often mounted on [[Technical (vehicle)|technicals]]). ===Armoured and transport vehicles=== The Tigers' own armoured corps was created in early 1976, equipped with an assortment of ex-[[Lebanese Army]] [[M41 Walker Bulldog]] and [[AMX-13]] [[light tanks]], [[Charioteer tank]]s, [[M42 Duster]] [[Self-propelled anti-aircraft weapon|SPAAG]]s,Kassis, ''30 Years of Military Vehicles in Lebanon'' (2003), p. 25. [[M113 armored personnel carrier|M113]] and [[Panhard M3|Panhard M3 VTT]]Kassis, ''30 Years of Military Vehicles in Lebanon'' (2003), p. 24.Kassis, ''Véhicules Militaires au Liban/Military Vehicles in Lebanon'' (2012), p. 56. [[Armoured personnel carrier]]s, [[Bravia Chaimite|Bravia V-200 Chaimite]] [[Armoured car (military)|armoured car]]s, [[T17 (armored car)|Staghound armoured car]]s,Ludovic Fortin, ''T17E1 Staghound Armored Car – Le char sur roues'', Trucks & Tracks Magazine, December 2007 - January 2008 issue, pp. 48-67. and [[Panhard AML|Panhard AML-90]] [[Armored car (military)|armoured cars]],Hamizrachi, ''The Emergence of South Lebanon Security Belt'' (1984), pp. 55-89.Badran, ''Lebanon: Liberation, Conflict, and Crisis'' (2010), pp. 50-52. bolstered by twenty Israeli-supplied [[Super Sherman|M50 Super Sherman]] Tanks,Kassis, ''Véhicules Militaires au Liban/Military Vehicles in Lebanon'' (2012), p. 62. [[M3 Half-track|M3/M9 Zahlam half-track]]s and [[BTR-152]] APCs. The NLP militia also raised a mechanized force of [[gun truck]]s or '[[Technical (vehicle)|technicals]]', comprising [[M151 1/4-ton 4x4 utility truck|M151A1]] and [[Willys M38A1|Willys M38A1 MD jeeps]],Kassis, ''30 Years of Military Vehicles in Lebanon'' (2003), p. 24. [[Land Rover Series|Land-Rover series II-III]],Kassis, ''30 Years of Military Vehicles in Lebanon'' (2003), p. 24.Kassis, ''Véhicules Militaires au Liban/Military Vehicles in Lebanon'' (2012), p. 58. [[Toyota Land Cruiser (J40)]], [[Toyota Land Cruiser (J45)]], [[Peugeot 404]], [[Dodge Power Wagon|Dodge Power Wagon W200]], [[GMC (automobile)|GMC]] Sierra Custom K25/K30, Chevrolet C-10 Cheyenne and Chevrolet C-20 Scottsdale light pickups, and [[Toyota Dyna|Toyota Dyna U10-series trucks]] fitted with [[heavy machine guns]], [[recoilless rifles]], and [[anti-aircraft]] [[autocannons]]. For logistical support, the Tigers relied on [[Range Rover|Range Rover 1st generation]] and [[Toyota Land Cruiser (J42)]] [[hardtop]] light pickups, [[Toyota Dyna|Toyota U10-series route vans (minibus)]],Kassis, ''Véhicules Militaires au Liban/Military Vehicles in Lebanon'' (2012), p. 67. Chevrolet Series 50 light-duty, Dodge F600 medium-duty and [[GMC (automobile)|GMC]] C7500 heavy-duty cargo trucks; a number of [[Volkswagen Type 2|Volkswagen Type 2 Transporter minibuses]] were used as military ambulances. ===Artillery=== They also fielded a powerful artillery corps equipped with British [[Ordnance QF 25-pounder|QF Mk III 25-Pounder field gun]]s, French [[Obusier de 155 mm Modèle 50|Mle 1950 BF-50 155mm howitzer]]s, Soviet [[130 mm towed field gun M1954 (M-46)|M1954 (M-46) 130mm towed field gun]]s, Soviet [[AZP S-60|AZP S-60 57mm anti-aircraft gun]]s,Jureidini, McLaurin, and Price, ''Military operations in selected Lebanese built-up areas'' (1979), pp. 16-21, 32-36, 52; Appendix A, A-10, Table 3; Appendix D, D-5. British [[Bofors 40 mm|Bofors 40mm L/60 anti-aircraft guns]][http://osw.zone/paint-weathering-diorama/vallejo-colors/135-btr-152-apc-armed-with-bofors-40-mm-gunnlp-tigers-militialebanon1976-by/ 1/35 Model Photos of a Lebanese Tigers Militia AA QF Bofors 40mm gun mounted on a BTR-152 APC, c.1976.] and [[anti-aircraft]] [[autocannons]]. The latter consisted of Yugoslav [[Zastava M55]] 20mm triple-barreled, Soviet [[ZPU|ZPU (ZPU-1, ZPU-2, ZPU-4)]] 14.5mm and [[ZU-23-2]] 23mm AA autocannons (mostly mounted on [[Technical (vehicle)|technicals]] and transport trucks), which were employed in both [[Anti-aircraft warfare|air defense]] and direct fire supporting roles. ==Illegal activities and controversy== Financing for the NLP militia came at first from both Chamoun’s personal fortune and from 'protection' [[racket (crime)|racket]]s collected in the areas under their control,Randall, ''Going All the Way'' (1984), p. 125. though they also received outside help. Conservative [[Arab people|Arab countries]] such as [[Jordan]] and the [[United States]], provided covert funding, weapons, ammunition, training and other non-lethal assistance.El-Kazen, ''The Breakdown of the State in Lebanon'' (2000), p. 304. Most of it entered towards the illegal port of [[Dbayeh]], set up in early 1976 and administered by Joseph Abboud, former personal [[chauffeur]] and hunting partner of Camille Chamoun, who run drug-smuggling and arms contraband activities on the behalf of the NLP until 1980, when the [[Lebanese Forces (militia)|Lebanese Forces]] brought the port under their control. Ruthless fighters with a reputation of aggressiveness, often initiating hostilities with the opposition side,McGowan, Roberts, Abu Khalil, and Scott Mason, ''Lebanon: a country study'' (1989), p. 240.Collelo, ''Lebanon: a country study'' (1989), p. 240. aggrivated by lack of discipline and restraint,Bavly & Salpeter, ''Fire in Beirut'' (1984), p. 52. they were involved in the [[Karantina massacre|Karantina]], [[Al-Masklah]] and [[Siege of Tel al-Zaatar|Tel al-Zaatar Massacre]]s of [[Palestinian refugee]]s in [[East Beirut]] and Dbayeh, allied with the [[Army of Free Lebanon]], [[Al-Tanzim]], [[Kataeb Regulatory Forces]], [[Lebanese Youth Movement (MKG)|Lebanese Youth Movement]] and the [[Guardians of the Cedars]]. Towards the end of the 1970s, however, rivalries within the [[Lebanese Front]] coalition strained the relationship between the NLP Tigers' militia and their erstwhile Christian allies, leading them to violent confrontation with the Phalangists and the Guardians of the Cedars. The Tigers' even battled these two factions in May 1979 for control of the [[Furn esh Shebbak]] and [[Ain el-Rammaneh]] districts in Beirut, and for the town of [[Akoura]] in the [[Matn District]].O'Ballance, ''Civil War in Lebanon'' (1998), p. 90. ==List of NLP Tigers Commanders== * [[Naim Berdkan]] (October 1968 – January 1976) * [[Dany Chamoun]] (January 1976 – July 1980) * [[Dory Chamoun]] (July – August 1980) ===NLP Tigers junior commanders=== *Abou Kamal *Frankie Nasrallah *[[Jean Eid]] *Bob Azzam *Dr [[Naji Hayek]] *[[Georges Aaraj]] *[[Elias El-Hannouche]] *[[Nouhad Chelhot]] ==The Tigers in the Lebanese civil war== ===Early expansion phase 1975-77=== Upon the outbreak of the civil war in April 1975, the NLP Tigers immediately engaged the leftist [[Lebanese National Movement]] (LNM) militias and their [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] PLO allies, being heavily committed in several battles in and outside the Beirut area. In October 1975, they supported their Phalangist allies of the [[Kataeb Regulatory Forces]] (KRF) militia against the [[Al-Mourabitoun]] and the [[Nasserite Correctionist Movement]] (NCM) for the control of the [[Battle of the Hotels|Hotels district in centre Beirut]].Jureidini, McLaurin, and Price, ''Military operations in selected Lebanese built-up areas'' (1979), p. 6.O'Ballance, ''Civil War in Lebanon'' (1998), p. 29. In January 1976 the collapse of the [[Lebanese Armed Forces]] (LAF) enabled the Tigers to take over Army barracks and depots located at Achrafieh, [[Ain el-Rammaneh]], [[Hadath, Baabda|Hadath]], [[Baabda]], and [[Hazmiyeh]] districts of [[East Beirut]], seizing heavy weapons and enrolling defectors into their ranks. The Tigers later joined in March that year the allied Christian [[Lebanese Front]] militias in the defense of the [[Mount Lebanon]] region and the [[Aley District]] against the combined LNM-PLO-[[Lebanese Arab Army]] (LAA) 'Spring Offensive'.Gordon, ''The Gemayels'' (1988), p. 50. During the [[Hundred Days' War]] in February 1978 the Tigers, backed by the [[Tyous Team of Commandos]] (TTC), put a spirited defence of the Achrafieh and [[Fayadieh]] districts in support of the [[Army of Free Lebanon]] (AFL) against the [[Syrian Army]]. === Reversals and decline 1978-1980 === The Tigers' involvement in the above-mentioned atrocities, however, cost them the loss of Iqlim al-Kharrub to the [[Lebanese National Movement|LNM]]-[[Palestine Liberation Organization|PLO]] [[Political alliance|alliance]] supported by [[Palestine Liberation Army]] units on 20-22 January 1976, which they failed to defend despite being backed by [[Internal Security Forces|ISF]] units and [[Lebanese Army]] troops.McGowan, Roberts, Abu Khalil, and Scott Mason, ''Lebanon: a country study'' (1989), p. 158.Hokayem, ''L'armée libanaise pendant la guerre: un instrument du pouvoir du président de la République (1975-1985)'' (2012), p. 21. The fall of this important stronghold was a severe blow to the NLP and the Tigers (coupled by the death of their commander [[Naim Berdkan]]), depriving them of their main recruiting area along with their local training infrastructure, chiefly the [[Es-Saadiyat]] camp, and the port towns of [[Damour]] and [[Jiyeh]]. Relations between the NLP political board and the Tigers' military command soured after the former, headed by [[Camille Chamoun]], supported [[Syrian occupation of Lebanon|Syria's military intervention in June that year]] whereas the latter, now led by Camille's son [[Dany Chamoun]], opposed it. Fearing that his own party's militia was getting out of control, Camille tacitly allowed the NLP's [[Kataeb]] rivals to absorb the Tigers into the [[Lebanese Forces (militia)|Lebanese Forces]] (LF) under [[Bachir Gemayel]].{{cn|date=March 2018}} Dany's adamant refusal of allowing the Tigers to be incorporated led to a Phalangist assault on his militia's headquarters in [[Safra, Lebanon|Safra]] on July 7, 1980, which resulted in [[Safra massacre|a massacre]] that claimed up to 500 lives, including civilians and 80 of Dany's men.Katz, Russel, and Volstad, ''Armies in Lebanon'' (1985), p. 8.Gordon, ''The Gemayels'' (1988), p. 58.McGowan, Roberts, Abu Khalil, and Scott Mason, ''Lebanon: a country study'' (1989), p. 240.Hoy and Ostrovsky, ''By Way of Deception'' (1990), p. 302.O'Ballance, ''Civil War in Lebanon'' (1998), p. 100.Menargues, ''Les Secrets de la guerre du Liban'' (2004), pp. 53-54. While their leader Dany was rushed to exile,Menargues, ''Les Secrets de la guerre du Liban'' (2004), p. 54. first to [[Syria]] and then to [[Europe]] after handling over the command of the Tigers to his elder brother [[Dory Chamoun]], the militia was officially disbanded on Camille's orders in late August. Soon afterwards, the Phalangists seized nearly all of the Tigers' positions in and outside [[East Beirut canton|East Beirut]], including the vital Naas and Adma training camps. The remaining 3,000 militiamen either surrendered their weapons and returned home or found themselves being consolidated by the end of October of that year into the [[Damouri Brigade]] within the [[Lebanese Forces (militia)|Lebanese Forces]].Menargues, ''Les Secrets de la guerre du Liban'' (2004), p. 55. === Revival and disbandment 1983-1990 === The [[1982 Lebanon War|Israeli invasion of Lebanon in June 1982]], coupled by the death of the LF supremo [[Bachir Gemayel]] in September that year brought the resurgence of the [[National Liberal Party (Lebanon)|National Liberals]] into the political scene, although the efforts by [[Camille Chamoun]] to revive the Tigers militia in 1983-84 proved less successful. The small force of only 100 or so lightly equipped fighters they gathered proved incapable of competing with the [[Lebanese Forces (militia)|Lebanese Forces]]' military might, being relegated to the role of a mere [[bodyguard]] for the NLP political leaders for the remainder of the war. Upon the end of the civilian strife in October 1990 and the subsequent assassination of [[Dany Chamoun]] – who had succeeded his late father at the NLP's presidency in October 1987 – the last remaining [[National Liberal Party (Lebanon)|National Liberals]]' paramilitary organization was disarmed on orders of the new [[Lebanese government]]. The NLP Tigers are no longer active. ==The Free Tigers== The '''Free Tigers''' ([[Arabic]]: ''Noumour Al-Horr'') or '''Lionceaux Libres''' in [[French language|French]], also known variously as the '''"Hannache Group"''', '''"Hannache's Tigers"''' or '''"Lionceaux d'Hannache"''', were a dissident splinter group of the NLP Tigers formed soon after the forcible merger of the latter into the [[Lebanese Forces (militia)|Lebanese Forces]] in July 1980. Defying the official orders to disband, about 200 Tigers' militiamen commanded by [[Elias El-Hannouche]] (''nom de guerre'' 'Hannache') went underground to wage a guerrilla war against the LF, operating in the [[Hadath, Baabda|Hadath]] and [[Ain el-Rammaneh]] districts of [[East Beirut]] from August to late October 1980. The Free Tigers are believed to have been responsible for some bomb and guerrilla attacks in East Beirut, including an ambush with combined rocket- and small-arms' fire on the U.S. Embassador's motorcade in August that year (intended to discredit the LF), followed on 10 November by two [[car-bomb]] explosions on the [[Achrafieh]] quarter that left 10 dead and 62 wounded.Menargues, ''Les Secrets de la guerre du Liban'' (2004), pp. 55-56. Defeated after a four-day street battle despite being backed by [[Lebanese Army]] troops sent upon request of the NLP president [[Camille Chamoun]]Kechichian, ''The Lebanese Army: Capabilities and Challenges in the 1980s'' (1985), p. 25.O'Ballance, ''Civil War in Lebanon'' (1998), p. 103. and forced out in mid-November of their last remaining strongholds at Ain el-Rammaneh by the LF, Hannache and a number of its dissident Tigers fled across the [[Green Line (Lebanon)|Green Line]] into the Muslim-controlled western sector of the Lebanese Capital.Menargues, ''Les Secrets de la guerre du Liban'' (2004), p. 56. There they placed themselves under the protection of the [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] [[Fatah]] intelligence service before moving to the Syrian-controlled [[Beqaa Valley]]. On 14 December 1980, Hannache and 50 Free Tigers' militiamen stormed and seized the Hoch el-Oumara suburb of [[Zahlé]], before being driven out by local LF units the following day; the Free Tigers returned to Zahlé on December 20 and managed to seize by force the former NLP party offices' but they were resisted by the LF and subsequently forced to withdraw from the town on December 22 under [[Syrian Army]] protection.Mclaurin, ''The battle of Zahle'' (1986), pp. 6-7.Menargues, ''Les Secrets de la guerre du Liban'' (2004), p. 57. The Free Tigers seemed to have remained operational until 1981, though very little was heard from them afterwards. ==Legacy== Since 2002, several former NLP Tigers' commanders known for their right-wing, ultra-nationalist leanings rallied in support of General [[Michel Aoun]] and went on to occupy various key positions within the Aounist [[Free Patriotic Movement]] (FPM) hierarchy, ranging from political (Dr [[Naji Hayek]] and [[Georges Aaraj]]) to security ([[Jean Eid]] and Bob Azzam). == See also == * [[Damour massacre]] * [[National Liberal Party (Lebanon)]] * [[Lebanese Front]] * [[Lebanese Forces (militia)|Lebanese Forces]] * [[Lebanese Civil War]] * [[Safra massacre]] * [[South Lebanon Army]] * [[Tyous Team of Commandos]] * [[Phoenicianism]] * [[Weapons of the Lebanese Civil War]] * [[Zahliote Group]] ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== * Afaf Sabeh McGowan, John Roberts, As'ad Abu Khalil, and Robert Scott Mason, ''Lebanon: a country study'', area handbook series, Headquarters, Department of the Army (DA Pam 550-24), Washington D.C. 1989. - {{Infobox Political party |country = Armenia |native_name = Հայաստանի Միավորված Կոմունիստական Կուսակցության |logo = |leader = [[Yuri Manoukian]] |president = |chairperson = |spokesperson = |leader1_name = |leader2_name = |leader3_name = |foundation = July 7, 2003 |dissolution = |headquarters = [[Yerevan]] |position = [[Left-wing]] |newspaper = |youth_wing = |membership_year= |membership = |ideology = [[Communism]]
[[Marxism–Leninism]]
[[Soft euroscepticism]] |national = |affiliation1_title=Continental affiliation |affiliation1=[[Communist Party of the Soviet Union (2001)|Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] |europarl = |colors = |colorcode = red |website = |footnotes = |name=}} The '''United Communist Party of Armenia''' ({{lang-hy|Հայաստանի Միավորված Կոմունիստական Կուսակցության}}, abbreviated ՀՄԿԿ / HMKK, ''Hayastani Miatsial Komunistakan Kusaktsutyun'') is a communist [[political party]] in [[Armenia]]. It was formed on July 7, 2003 through the merger of: *'''[[Renewed Communist Party of Armenia]]''' - (in [[Armenian language|Armenian]]: Հայաստանի նորացված կոմունիստական կուսակցություն ''Hayastani Noratsvats Komunistakan Kusaktsutyun'') abbreviated HNKK, formed on May 25, 2002, by former [[Armenian Communist Party]] (HKK) leaders Yuri Manukian and Grant Voskanyan who had been expelled from HKK the previous year on the grounds that they had advocated cooperation with the government. Manukian became the First Secretary of the Central Committee of the United Communist Party of Armenia *'''[[Armenian Workers Communist Party]]''' - (in [[Armenian language|Armenian]]: Հայաստանի աշխատավորության կոմունիստական կուսակցություն ''Hayastani Ashkhatavorutian Komunistakan Kusaktsutiun'') *'''[[Armenian Workers Union]]''' - (in [[Armenian language|Armenian]]: Հայ աշխատավորների միություն) founded in 1999. *'''[[Union of Communists of Armenia]]''' - (in [[Armenian language|Armenian]]: Հայաստանի կոմունիստների միություն). In the 2003 [[elections in Armenia|elections]], the party formed part of the [[Free and Fair Armenia]] electoral bloc before joining the United Communist Party of Armenia. *'''[[Marxist Party of Armenia]]''' - (in [[Armenian language|Armenian]]:Հայաստանի մարքսիստական կուսակցություն) The Marxist Party of Armenia had registered in 1997, but failed to get re-registered by 1 January 2001. In the 2003 [[elections in Armenia|elections]], the party formed part of the [[Free and Fair Armenia]] electoral bloc before joining the United Communist Party of Armenia. *Party of Intellectuals. The HMKK held its first congress on March 25, 2004. [[Yuri Manoukian]] was elected First Secretary of the party. The meeting saw the election of a 77-member [[Central Committee]] and a 17-member [[Politburo]]. The HMKK considers itself as a "constructive opposition party". It has closer links to the government than the main [[Armenian Communist Party]] and does not join opposition fronts. The HMKK extended its support to the successful presidential bid of Defense Minister [[Serzh Sargsyan]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1341722.html|title=Caucasus Report: May 30, 2005|date=2005-05-30|website=Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306031309/http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1341722.html|archive-date=2016-03-06}} ==See also== *[[Communist Party of Armenia (disambiguation)]] *[[Communist Party of Armenia (Soviet Union)]] *[[Armenian Communist Party]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Armenian political parties}} [[Category:2003 establishments in Armenia]] [[Category:Communist parties in Armenia]] [[Category:Eurosceptic parties]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2003]] [[Category:Political parties in Armenia]] {{Armenia-party-stub}} {{CP-stub}}

{{About||the TV series|Village Hall (TV series)|the historic building|Village Hall (Sheffield, Illinois)}}
A '''village hall''' is usually a building and gathering place in a [[village]]. It may also serve multiple other functions.
==United Kingdom== [[Image:BSH SW P1010018.JPG|thumb|right|[[Bedhampton]] Social Hall, United Kingdom]] In the [[United Kingdom]], a '''village hall''' is usually a building within a village which contains at least one large room, usually owned by and run for the benefit of the local community. Such a hall is typically used for a variety of public and private functions, such as: *[[Parish councils in England|Parish council]] meetings *[[Polling station]] for local and national elections *Sports club functions *[[community theater|Local drama productions]] *Dances *[[Jumble sale]]s *Private parties such as birthdays or wedding receptions
Village halls sometimes have [[Charitable organization|charitable]] status.<ref>[http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/Library/guidance/cc18text.pdf Use of Church Halls for Village Hall and Other Charitable Purposes], ''[[Charity Commission]]'', [[United Kingdom]], July 2001.</ref> They may have other names such as a Village Institute or Memorial Hall. In some localities a [[church hall]] or [[community centre]] provides similar functions.
The word ''neuadd'' ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: /'neiæð/) is used to refer to village halls in Welsh-speaking parts of [[Wales]], as in {{lang|cy|Neuadd Dyfi}}, the village hall in [[Aberdyfi]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neuadddyfi.co.uk |title=Neuadd Dyfi |accessdate=2 November 2009 }}</ref>
==United States== [[Image:La Grange, Illinois Village Hall.jpg|thumb|[[La Grange, Illinois]] Village Hall]] In the [[United States]], a '''village hall''' is the seat of government for [[village]]s. It functions much as a [[town hall]] or [[city hall]].
== See also == * [[Church hall]] * [[Community centre]] * [[Function hall]] * [[Local community]] * [[Meeting house]] * [[Moot hall]]

{{Infobox political party |name = Zionist Socialist Workers Party |native_name = Сионистско-социалистическая рабочая партия |ideology = [[Socialism]]
[[Zionism]] |position = [[Left wing]] |merged = [[United Jewish Socialist Workers Party]] |founded = 1905 }} '''Zionist-Socialist Workers Party''' ({{lang-ru|Сионистско-социалистическая рабочая партия}}), often referred to simply as '''Zionist-Socialists''' or '''S.S.''' by their [[Russian language|Russian]] initials, was a [[Jew]]ish [[socialist]] [[Jewish Territorialist Organization|territorialist]] [[political party]] in the [[Russian Empire]] and [[Poland]], that emerged from the ''Vozrozhdenie'' (Renaissance) group in 1904. The party held its founding conference in [[Odessa]] in 1905.{{cite journal |last=Alroey |first=Gur |title=Demographers in the service of the nation: Liebmann Hersch, Jacob Lestschinsky, and the early study of Jewish migration |journal=Jewish History |year=2006 |volume=20 |pages=265–282}}{{cite web |author= V. I. Lenin |title=Uniters |url=http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1912/jun/17d.htm |publisher=Marxists Internet Archive |accessdate=2014-11-24}} sourced from {{cite book |title=Lenin Collected Works |publisher=Progress Publishers |year=1975 |location=Moscow |volume=18 |pages=118–121 |others=Stepan Apresyan, translator}} sourced from {{cite journal |journal=Sotsial-Demokrat |number=27 |date=June 17, 1912}}{{cite book |title=Plotzk (Płock): a History of an Ancient Jewish Community in Poland |editor=Eliyahu Eisenberg |publisher=Hamenora |location=Tel Aviv |year=1967 |url=http://www.zchor.org/plock/sefer2.htm |others=Ada Holtzman, translator}} In the same year the party sent delegates, among them [[Nachman Syrkin]], to the Basle Seventh Zionist Congress.{{cite book|last=Frankel|first=Jonathan|title=Prophecy and politics: socialism, nationalism, and the Russian Jews, 1862–1917|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1984|pages=686|isbn=978-0-521-26919-3|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-ycwctuCSpQC}} However, while the mainstream Zionist movement rejected the idea of a Jewish state anywhere but in [[Eretz Yisrael]], the Russian party favoured the idea of a Jewish territorial autonomy, outside of [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]].Ėstraĭkh, G. ''In Harness: Yiddish Writers' Romance with Communism. Judaic traditions in literature, music, and art.'' [[Syracuse, New York]]: Syracuse University Press, 2005. p. 30 Moreover, while territorial autonomy was the goal of the party, it dedicated most of its energy into revolutionary activities in Russia. Like other Russian revolutionary groups such as the [[Narodniks]], the party was positive towards using [[terrorism]] as a means of struggle against the establishment.[[Anna Geifman|Geifman, Anna]]. ''Thou Shalt Kill: Revolutionary Terrorism in Russia, 1894–1917''. [[Princeton, New Jersey]]: Princeton University Press, 1993. p. 35 [[Nachman Syrkin]], [[Jacob Lestschinsky]], [[Volf Latsky-Bartoldi]] and [[Shmuel Niger]] were among the leading figures of the party.Frankel, Jonathan (ed.). ''The Jews and the European crisis, 1914–1921''. [[New York City|New York]]: Oxford University Press, 1988. p. 339 The party played an active role in the [[Russian Revolution of 1905|1905 revolution]]. At the 7th congress of the [[World Zionist Organization]] in 1905, the WZO formally rejected the '[[British Uganda Programme|Uganda Plan]]' (a proposal to resettle Jews in [[East Africa]]) after sharp debates. In response, the party and other territorialists withdrew from the WZO. The party grew rapidly, and became the second largest Jewish labour party after the [[General Jewish Labour Bund in Lithuania, Poland and Russia|Bund]]. The party organized 'neutral' [[trade union]]s, in opposition to the Bundist unions. In the end of 1906, the party claimed a membership of 27 000. However, after 1906 the influence of the party began to decline sharply. Many leaders went into exile in Western Europe. The central organ of the party was the weekly [[Yiddish]] newspaper ''Der nayer veg'', published from [[Vilna]] 1906–1907. The newspaper was closed down by the authorities in 1907.{{cite web |title=Newspapers and Periodicals |publisher=YIVO Institute |url=http://www.yivoinstitute.org/pdf/newspapers_periodicals.pdf |accessdate=2014-11-24}} During the 1907 [[Stuttgart]] congress of the [[Second International]], the [[International Socialist Bureau]] decided to give a consultative vote to the party at the congress. The decision was, however, overturned a year later.Frankel, Jonathan. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=-ycwctuCSpQC Prophecy and Politics: Socialism, Nationalism, and the Russian Jews, 1862–1917]''. [[Cambridge]]: Cambridge University Press, 1981. p. 283Jacobs, Jack Lester. ''Jewish Politics in Eastern Europe: The Bund at 100''. Basingstoke: Palgrave, 2001. p. 185 In 1911 party, the [[Jewish Socialist Workers Party]] and [[Poalei Zion]] signed a joint appeal to the [[International Socialist Bureau]], asking the International to recognize the national character of the Jewish people. In 1917 the party merged with the Jewish Socialist Workers Party, forming the [[United Jewish Socialist Workers Party]].Jaff Schatz. Jews and the communist movement in interwar Poland. In: Jonathan Frankel. [https://books.google.com/books?id=POkxdm6DoAsC&pg=PA13&lpg=PA13&dq=jaff+schatz+jews+communism&source=web&ots=B5QNMKyJ49&sig=KW-p4_cdwuVM_kHyU9zifzYbX8M&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result#PPA30,M1 ''Dark Times, Dire Decisions: Jews and Communism. Studies in Contemporary Jewry.''] Oxford University Press US, 2005, p. 79. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:1904 establishments in the Russian Empire]] [[Category:1917 disestablishments in Russia]] [[Category:Defunct socialist parties in Poland]] [[Category:Defunct socialist parties in Russia]] [[Category:Jewish political parties]] [[Category:Jewish socialism]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1917]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1904]] [[Category:Political parties in the Russian Empire]] [[Category:Political parties of minorities in Poland]] [[Category:Political parties of minorities in Russia]] [[Category:Political parties of the Russian Revolution]] [[Category:Territorialism]] [[Category:Zionism in Poland]] [[Category:Zionism in Russia]] [[Category:Zionist political parties]]
